ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Parry Sound, Ontario,
May 9th, 1939.

Dear Sir:

Miss Patricia Coughlin, teacher of the Magnetewan Indian Day School advises me that a requisition which she made for school supplies sometime ago has not yet been filled, and she is completely out of some essentials. Will you kindly take this matter up with the proper department?

Thanking you, I am,

Yours truly,

SAMUEL DEVLIN,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ontario.
Extract from Inspector Bennett's report on the Magnetawan Indian day school visited on June 1, 1939.

These pupils need a softball, football and bat.

2 Brooms, 1 axe and ten yards of mosquito netting have been asked for and not yet received. The mosquitoes are a real pest just now.

(Sgd.) J.W. Bennett,
Inspector of Schools.
Ottawa,
June 14, 1939.

Dear Sir:

Please deliver to room 503, Booth Building, for the Magnetawan Indian day school, 1 playground ball, 1 football and 1 playground bat.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Geo. Bourne, Esq.,
149 Rideau Street,
Ottawa, Ont.
Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 9th instant enclosing requisition for supplies for the Magnetawan Indian day school you may purchase 2 brooms, 1 axe, 20 yards cheese cloth, 1 floor mop and 1 scrub brush. The playground ball, bat and football are being ordered by the Department and will be sent to the teacher.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

S. Devlin, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Parry Sound, Ont.

Mr. S. Devlin, Indian Agent, Parry Sound, Ont.

As requested, the previous teacher, Miss Rita Dupuis, forwarded to the Department on May 1 last, through your office, a requisition for supplies that she considered would be required at the Magnetawan Indian Day School during the academic year 1943-44. I am now in receipt of the attached statements from the Public Printing and Stationery Branch with regard to the articles that have been shipped. They forwarded these addressed "The Teacher" but they have been returned. We overlooked advising them that we have not yet secured a teacher for this school and presumably the supplies are at Byng Inlet. It would be appreciated if you would accept delivery of the parcel and keep it at your office until a teacher is secured. If we do not obtain a teacher within the next month or so, you can open the parcel and return to this office the Corona Readers. As soon as you have checked the parcel you should sign the attached advices from the Stationery Office and return them to the Department of Public Printing and Stationery, Ottawa, Ontario.

Sir,

Enclosed please find sketch of proposed school building at Maganetawan Reserve, along with approximate cost of material and labour for building same.

I beg to state that the cost of material is the cheapest and best procurable in the District. I should also state that Mr. Wood, the foreman whom I propose having, has had experience building schools in the west. He informs me that he would want to be inside of two weeks if I want him, after that he will be employed on summer cottage work.

I can assure the Dept. that the building planned will be suitable and comfortable. The price, as given, is for the actual work. Such as cupboards for teacher's house would have to be allowed for.

By starting right away, I should be able to get the Indians before the tourist trade starts, and before the railways start their summer work. Mr. Wood informs me that with the help of the Indians, he can complete the whole, in six weeks. By waiting until the month, the wage bill would be considerably more.

Awaiting your reply and instructions.

I have the honour to be,

Sir:

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

April 11, 1924.

Honourable Charles Stewart,

There are at Byng Inlet about twenty children who are members of the Magenetswan Indian band. It has come, I believe, for the establishment of a school on the reserve. In the past some have been recruited to Indian residential schools; these institutions in the East are filled to accommodation.

The Agent is prepared to secure a teacher to erect by day labour a small day school residence. He has submitted a budget approved by the Department which is $2,450 and I should be pleased to instruct the Agent to include an item in the Estimates.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Honourable Charles Stewart,

There are at Byng Inlet about twenty children of school age who are members of the Maganetawan Indian Band. The time has come, I believe, for the establishment of a day school on the reserve. In the past some of the children have been recruited to Indian residential schools, but these institutions in the East are filled to the limit of their accommodation.

The Indian Agent is prepared to secure a competent foreman and to erect by day labour a small day school and a teacher's residence. He has submitted a rough sketch, which has been approved by the Department Architect. The estimated cost is $2,450 and I should be pleased to have your authority to instruct the Agent to proceed with the work. There is an item in the Estimates for this building.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Send the following message, subject to the terms on back hereof, which are hereby agreed to

Ottawa, April 17, 1924.

Sir:

I have your No. T-41 of the 7th instant with enclosures, with reference to the proposed school building on the Maganetowan Reserve. I am pleased to inform you that the Department has given favourable consideration to your recommendation and I have to confirm my telegram of today's date as follows:

"Authority to erect school Maganetowan mailed today."

You may purchase the lumber and other materials enumerated on the enclosed lists. Please secure competitive prices from the best available sources of supply, and when you are forwarding properly certified accounts, in duplicate, in favour of the firms given the business, please support them with Abstract of Tender forms showing the firms asked to quote and the prices quoted. You may secure a foreman and other carpenters and under your supervision erect the school building on a day labour basis. Indian labour should be engaged when practicable. Proper time sheets in duplicate, showing the hours and receipts of the men employed, should be kept and in due course forwarded to the Department. An accountable cheque of $500 will be directed to you under separate cover, for the wages of men. Do not pay any accounts for materials. These shall be sent to the Department for payment.

The sketches you had prepared are also returned herewith.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Enclos.

John M. Daly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 17th instant, with reference to the desks required for the new school building on the Maganeetawan Indian Reserve.

In reply I beg to say that before an order is placed further information is required. School desks are manufactured in the following sizes, viz:

No. 6 - Pupils 5 to 8 years,
No. 5 - 6 to 10",
No. 4 - 9 to 14",
No. 3 - 12 to 16".

Please state the number of rows it is intended to set up in the classroom. If the desks are arranged in 4 rows, I would suggest that the following seating arrangement be carried out, viz: 4 fronts No. 6 and 4 single desks No. 6; 8 single desks No. 5; 12 single desks No. 4; 4 single desks No. 3 and 4 rear seats No. 3. This would provide seating accommodation for 32 pupils seating 8 to each row of desks. If this is more desks than required, please state the number you would advise be furnished and how they will be arranged, also give full shipping directions.

Besides the school desks, we will supply a teacher's desk and chair and two visitors' chairs.

Please state whether a cupboard is required, or if you will arrange to have a suitable cupboard built in the classroom in which to store books and school material. It is considered that it might be cheaper to have this done than to purchase a cupboard.

You should also furnish the dimensions of the blackboard required. We now supply beaverplate blackboards today schools. This is manufactured in widths of 3', 3½' and 4', and up to 12' in length.

As soon as the above information is received, an order will be placed for the desks, etc.

You will be advised in a separate communication regarding the admission of white children and the fees that will be charged.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir,

Replying to yours of 23rd, 22-8-5, re school desks and blackboard for the Maganetawan school, I beg to state that your suggestion of desks would appear to be the correct thing for this school. The number of desks required at present as far as I can see is about thirty, but there are a few children who are about school age and your finding some to suit the situation perfectly. The space allotted for blackboards is 16 ft., and if we could get it all income so much the better, if not, whatever way is suitable will be made to suit.

I am having a cupboard built as it will be so much cheaper than to buy one. I think that it will save money by having the desks sent put up as the foreman carpenter will be through this week, and none of the Indians are over-smart at putting them up.

I am a little disappointed at the progress last week, but on the whole, I think I'm getting value for the money being spent.

The Indian labour is very slow as the building is progressing they are so pleased, the foreman tells me they would like to stop every ten minutes and admire their work. When I estimated, I estimated for a rush job. On the whole perhaps I expect too much. One thing I can assure the Dept., it will be a nice little school and the best value for the money in this part of the country. I would have liked a storm porch on the main building but perhaps later on I will be able to get an appropriation for this porch.

Have all desks and other supplies shipped to Byng Inlet to Samuel Noganosh (Chief) of the Maganetawan Band. It makes them feel good to have it done that way and they take a greater interest in the work. I will have to have the supplies carted onto the reserve, which will cost a little more. The road is very rough and they will have to make quite a few trips. However, rest assured I will keep the cost down as much as possible.

Trusting that this will meet with the approval of the Dept.

I have the honour to be,

Sir:

Your obedient servant,

Agent.

Sir:

I have your letter dated the 26th instant, regarding the desks and blackboard required for the new school which is being erected on the Maganetawan reserve.

We are obtaining prices for the supplying of the desks, and, as soon as the order is placed, you will be advised. An order will also be placed with the Government Stationery Office to supply 1 - 16' green hyloplate blackboard, 4' wide, with the necessary chalk trough and moulding. When shipment of the desks is being made, they will be forwarded addressed to the Chief, as requested by you. As it is not intended that the school will open until on or about September 1st, next, it is hoped that all furnishings and supplies will be in place before that date.

Have any arrangements been made for the providing of closets and for the storage of fuel? If not, would you recommend that the same be erected? It is preferred that separate closets with screened approaches be erected. If it is intended that a woodshed be erected, one building with a closet in either end and a separate apartment for fuel in the centre might be suitable. However, we will be pleased to have your recommendation, together with an estimate of the cost of any work which you would recommend be undertaken.

Regarding the installing of a bell, which you refer to in your letter No. T-36 of the 19th instant, I beg to say that the Department is not prepared to incur the expenditure required for this purpose at the present time.

He explained to me that owing to the school having to be shellacked before being varnished that it was the same as a two coat job ad made the varnish set up better and of course took more time. There was not enough of inside V-joint to complete the inside of teacher's house so I had to order 20' of more and 30' of old wood. It will be Thursday of this week before the building is completed. There is platform built at front of school which was not estimated on, so that the door which opens out would not hang against the building and be knocked off the hinges. The inside of the school looks good with B.C. fir, shellacked and varnished with the windows done in white. There is also a platform shaped so, which was not estimated on and which of course takes time, along with the cupboard, which is done in B.C. fir, to correspond with the rest of the inside of school. I figured on two toilets, and have them built, but there is one required for teacher's use. I thought of putting it in the wood shed built 15' by 16', on frame plywood, clapboard outside and rough lumber sheeted inside to save clapboards when they are filling the wood in shed. I figured the whole building will cost in the neighbourhood of $400 dollars, that is allowing for a two coat job of paint, the same as the main building and the toilets.

As it is more economical to have all done at once I am ordering the lumber for the wood shed to be shipped this week so as to keep the men. I understand that the mill will start next week and it will make easy to get men. I trust the Dept. approves of my actions in this matter for I am indeed anxious to keep the cost down as much as possible. The price for lumber for wood shed will be the same as for main building as I am getting it from the same firm, Mark Rogers, Parry Sound.

The Dept. can rest assured that I will endeavour to keep the cost of everything down to the lowest. The estimated cost of lumber and labour, I will forward this week. I require a check for $23.00 to cover this week's pay sheet and as I purpose going right ahead with the wood shed, would ask the Dept. to forward the check for next week of $117.00. I figure, and Mr. Woods assures me that school, wood shed and everything will be completed not later than Thursday June 12th.

I have a bellfry built and would appreciate the Dept. re-considering the supplying of bell.

Trusting this will be satisfactory.

I have the honour to be,

Sir:

Your obedient servant,

Agent.

Secretary Dept. Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, in which you request authority to purchase the necessary furnishings for the teacher's residence in connection with the Magantawan Indian Day School and a stove for the classroom. In reply I have to say that you may purchase and have delivered a stove for the school, a kitchen stove and heater for the teacher's house. You should see that the stoves supplied are of a type and size suitable to meet the requirements. If possible, competitive prices should be obtained and the purchase made from the firm quoting the lowest price. Please forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the cost. Any stove pipes required may also be purchased.

Regarding the other furnishings which may be required in fitting up the teacher's living quarters, I shall be pleased if you will forward a list of the articles which you would recommend be supplied. It is expected that the teachers will provide certain supplies themselves. In making out the list, therefore, you should include only the articles absolutely necessary.

With reference to the material which was left over after the erection of the building, as mentioned in your letter of the 10th instant, I have to say that you may arrange for the disposal of the small quantities of bricks, shingles and lumber to the Indians of the reserve. As this material has all been included in the accounts which you forwarded and has been paid for and as the Indians are asking time for payment if it is sold to them, it is considered that you may divide it up among the Indians who would make use of it, without charge. The Department will leave in your hands the matter of disposing of the left over material as you see advisable. If any of it would be of future use, it should be stored.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Ottawa, September 5th, 1924.

Sir:

I have your telegram of the 4th instant, regarding the school material and blackboard required for the use of the new Maganetawan Indian Day School which has recently been opened.

In reply I beg to confirm the following telegram sent you today: -

"May purchase locally small quantity schoolroom supplies for Maganetawan School. Blackboard will be shipped at early date."

You should purchase and have forwarded to the school a small supply of text books and other classroom supplies sufficient to carry on for a short period. You should obtain from the teacher a requisition for the balance of the supplies she will require to the end of the present year, which you should forward to the Department, when the same will be ordered through the Government Stationery Office. Before leaving for the Christmas holidays, the teacher should prepare another requisition covering the supplies for the balance of the school year to June 30th, next, and this should also be forwarded.

Regarding the blackboard, it is regretted that the ordering of this was overlooked. We have taken the matter up with the Government Stationery Office and they will arrange for early delivery. We are supplying a beaver plate blackboard, 16'x4', with the necessary chalk trough and moulding. This will be shipped care of Chief Nogansh, Byng Inlet. You should arrange to have it placed in position when it arrives.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, furnishing an estimate of the cost of building a porch to the Maganetawan Indian Day School, and enclosing an estimate of the lumber and other material required.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of having this porch built. You may, therefore, arrange for the purchase of the lumber and materials required and for the labour in having the work done. The quotation which you forwarded is returned herewith for your information. The Department would like, if possible, that you obtain other prices for this material, and purchase the same from the dealer quoting the lowest price. Proper time sheets, in duplicate, should be kept for the labour employed. If this work is undertaken before the school closes, as little interruption as possible should occur in the classroom activities. Please furnish properly certified vouchers covering the cost of the lumber, paint and other materials. This should be accompanied by a memorandum showing the names of the firms asked to quote for supplying same and the prices quoted. The total cost of the porch should, if possible, be kept down to the estimate submitted by you of approximately $243.

Regarding the fence, you may purchase the posts, fencing and 2 gates, and arrange for the labour in putting up the fence. The total cost of the material and labour for the fence should not exceed your estimate of $48.20. You should also forward properly receipted vouchers for the material and labour for the purpose.

MEMO.

R. T. Harris, Esq.,
Chief Indian Education

Dear Mr. Harris,

Have sent forward bill for scrubbing of Magnetawan School in favour of Michael Hoganworth for year 1926-1927.

I have to explain that I have tried to have this work done by caretakers but as no one the caretaker will rather give up the job.

He's done a good one as I insist that the school be kept scrubbed.

I could not get another person to give the same satisfaction and concerning the salary for caretaking I think it should be paid.

I have a fine teacher at this school and can see the effect of her work on the pupils.

Trusting you will pass this bill through and thank you for your consideration.

Yours Truly,

John McVay

Ottawa, November 3, 1927.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Maganetawan Indian Day School, recommends that sewing, which had been taught previously at this school, be continued and that the following supplies be furnished:

- 2 yds. plain white cotton cloth,
- 3 skeins green cotton floss,
- 3 " red " "
- 2 spools white cotton tape 1 inch wide,
- 4 yds. "Indian Head" cloth.

Please arrange for the purchase and delivery of the above materials and forward a properly certified voucher, in duplicate, covering the cost.

The Inspector states, further, that there was no kindling wood at the school. I should be pleased if you would arrange for the purchase and delivery of the quantity of kindling wood required for the coming winter's use. You should see that a good, dry quality of wood is obtained and that it is stored at the school. Please forward the account covering the cost in the usual manner.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INSPECTOR McGOOKIN,
DATED SEPTEMBER 15TH, 1930, REGARDING HIS RECENT
VISIT OF INSPECTION TO THE PARRY SOUND AGENCY.

Original on File 77-22.

I beg to submit the following report on my recent visit of inspection to the Parry Sound Agency.

Maganeetawan Day School:- Some of the floor joists have given way causing the floor to sag badly. Part of the flooring will have to be taken up and new joists put in. About 250 feet of flooring will be spoiled and have to be replaced. The work, including labour and new material, will cost approximately $90.00. This school needs painting outside and inside of porch. This should be done this year if funds are available.
Ottawa, September 25, 1930.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McGookin, in a report on his recent visit to the Waganetawan Indian Day School, reports regarding the school building as follows:

"Some of the floor joists have given way causing the floor to sag badly. Part of the flooring will have to be taken up and new joists put in. About 250 feet of flooring will be spoiled and have to be replaced. The work, including labour and new material, will cost approximately $90.00. This school needs painting outside and inside of porch."

The Department has no funds at the present time to provide the expense required in having the above work carried out this year, and the repairs and painting will have to stand over until next Summer. I have to request that you will draw this matter to the attention of the Department early next Spring, stating, in detail, the work you would advise be carried out in order to place this school building in good condition. Please state the approximate cost involved and how you would recommend that the work be carried out.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. M. Daly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Parry Sound, Ont.
The Secretary,
Department Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

Yours of Sept. 25th, 28-8-5, received, re Inspector McGoogins recommendations for repairs to the Magnetawan Indian Day School, I have to report that the repairs to the joists and flooring should be attended to right away. I refrained from reporting on this matter knowing that Mr. McGoogan would be in this vicinity and was under the impression that when he would report and show the great need of these repairs that the Department would sanction the cost.

The repairing of the joisting in this school would not be expensive, it would be the tearing up of the flooring, and the time spent pulling up and replacing it that would cost the most. I feel there is a reflection on this Agency and on the Department if these repairs are not attended to right away. So far as the painting is concerned that would lie over until next year, but the flooring should be done right away. I can assure the Department that if this expenditure, which I shall watch very closely, is granted, that I will keep it as low as possible.

Trusting this will be satisfactory,

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Agent.

JMD/BK.
Ottawa, October 1, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, regarding the repairs required to the joists and flooring in the Maganetawan Indian Day School building.

In reply I have to say that, in view of your report as to the urgency of this work, the Department will approve of your arranging to have the repairs required carried out. It is noted that it will be necessary to have the floor taken up, new joists put in and the flooring relaid. The Department will rely on you to see that all the work is completed in a satisfactory manner and at the lowest possible expense. You should arrange to purchase any materials required and for the labour in having the work carried out. After these repairs have been completed, please forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

The matter of the painting of this school will have to stand over until next Spring, at which time you should draw same to the attention of the Department, giving particulars as requested in our letter of the 25th ultimo.

Ottawa, August 18, 1932.

Sir:

With reference to previous correspondence regarding the painting of the Magnetawan Indian Day School building, I have to say that you may arrange to have this work carried out at an early date as possible, provided you are able to secure a satisfactory quotation, covering the cost of the paint and other materials and for the labour. If you consider it would be more advantageous and cheaper for you to purchase the paint and other materials required and arrange for the labour, you may have the work done in this manner. However, if you are of the opinion that it would be cheaper to accept the lowest quotation which you received for the work, of approximately $130, you may accept same. The Department will leave the matter of the painting of this building in your hands, to have the work performed at the lowest possible cost.

It is understood that the painting required includes two coats to the outside of the school, two coats on the inside of the teacher's house and that the toilets are to be painted. In your letter of May 12th, last, you estimated the cost to be $125. You should see that the work is satisfactorily performed and that a good grade of paint is used. After the painting has been completed, please forward accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred. If the work is done by day labour you should keep proper time sheets in triplicate, for the labour employed. These should be signed by the individual labourers, certified by yourself and forwarded for payment. It is hoped that you can have the painting at this school completed at an early date.

All accounts should be kept separately, covering the cost of the work at each of the schools which you have been authorized to have painted.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of a requisition which you forwarded from the teacher of the Maganetawan Indian Day School for supplies for the use of the school and teacher's living quarters.

You should obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost of the above supplies. These you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment. The purchase and delivery of the above supplies should receive your early attention.

The teacher visited the Department yesterday and requested that outside windows and a storm door be provided for the residence part of the school building. It is thought that the supplying and installing of the storm windows and door would not entail a large expenditure, and would add to the comfort and warmth of the teacher's living quarters. I would, therefore, request that you arrange to have same installed, keeping the expense for the purpose as low as possible. After the work has been completed, you should forward an account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Ottawa, June 28, 1933.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Magnetawan Indian Day School, has drawn attention to the condition of the school building. He states as follows:-

"The building is sinking in the centre of the classroom. Evidently, the timbers underneath the centre floor have decayed. The slope to the centre of the classroom and in the kitchen is considerable. Even the chimney has dropped. I feel it is a dangerous situation. This school is only up 8 years and why it is collapsing in the middle is hard to understand."

The Department would like to have a report from you, regarding the present condition of the building. As no funds have been provided for repairs to this school during the present fiscal year, it is doubtful if we could authorize any extensive work. However, I shall be pleased if you will state what is required to have the foundation of the building placed in good condition and the approximate cost of the necessary material and labour.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. M. Daly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Parry Sound, Ont.
Sir;

Replying to yours of June 28th 22-8-5 re the condition of the foundations of the Magnetawan Indian Day School, the building is sinking, and on the repairs recently done on the one side of the building, it was found that the foundations are in quicksand. I do not think that the situation is at all dangerous, and I would have made requisition to have the building fixed, but I was marking time until such times as there would be more funds available.

It will be necessary to have the floor torn up and have new joists and some flooring. Some of the joists there can be used over again, but some have to be replaced. This is a job that I cannot state just exactly how much it will cost, because I do not know how many joists and how much flooring will be required, until the flooring is taken up. When the building was being built there were vent holes put in for the preservation of the joisting and flooring, but it appears this was not sufficient.

I can get labour on the reserve and a man to do this work. I do not think there is anything dangerous about the situation. It is very inconvenient and very annoying to me to see the building going as it is. I think the best way to do is to put the two men that I have in view on the job to tear up the floor and then I will have a better idea of what has to be done. What I can guarantee is that there never was a better time to get work done than right now.
I wish to state emphatically that I do not agree with the Inspector's remark that there is anything dangerous about the situation. I am very proud of the schools and the condition they are in, and quite annoyed about this school, however with quicksand even the wisest people can be deceived.

I would suggest to the Department that they give me permission to go ahead and take a section of the floor up, then it can be seen what is required. I can give instructions to save the flooring as much as possible and will keep down the costs. Until the flooring is taken up I cannot estimate just exactly what the repairs would cost. This work can be done during the vacation.

A reply from the Department at their earliest will be very much appreciated.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, regarding the condition of the foundation of the Magnetawan Indian Day School. It is noted you do not consider that the situation is dangerous. As it would involve considerable expense to have new joists put in and the flooring replaced, it is thought that, unless urgent, the repairing of the foundation of this building could stand over until next year. Our funds are extremely limited, and, unless you believe the work should be done at once, the Department will not be prepared to authorize the expenditure. However, if you consider it is necessary that the repairs should be made to the foundation this summer, you may have the flooring taken up, in order to ascertain what new joists and work to the foundation would be required. After this has been done, it will, no doubt, be possible for you to furnish an estimate as to the material required and the cost of the labour in having the foundation placed in good condition and any repairs necessary to the flooring completed.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

Replying to yours of July 4th, 22-8-5, I have been to the Magnetawan Indian Day School and went thoroughly into the situation and I find that the foundation of the school is all right. The cause of the trouble there is a dry rot on the joists.

I have explained the situation to the caretaker and his grandson and they will be able to handle the situation, and do all the repairs that are necessary. This will save bringing a carpenter in there. Enclosed find a rough sketch of what I think is necessary for the preservation of the joists. There was a vent hole in the foundation but it was not sufficient and I find that at the back of the building where the teachers house is, there is a certain dampness. The enclosed sketch is what I think is necessary to preserve the timbers from rotting in the future or at least to preserve them for a much longer time.

When the flooring is up a ditch will be dug the whole length of the school and two cross ditches; and they will be arranged so that the water will run into one of the ditches running across, out to the side of the school, and will be an outlet for any water that might happen to collect. In this way there will be a through current of air both ways. This can be done when the floor is taken up, and at very little cost. The cost will be the time of the labour. I have explained all this to the caretaker and his grandson and they understand what is required. At the vents in the foundation, I have arranged for the caretaker to have flat stones put across the opening resting on two stones which will prevent the foundation from cracking.
This, on paper, might appear to be a big job, but it is not a big job. I think it is absolutely necessary to do this to prevent the same thing occurring again because dry rot seems to be quite prevalent in that section of the country. I have noticed at Byng Inlet and Britt where the houses are built on low foundations on flat found that they have all sunk more or less.

I am getting prices on the lumber, and nails required, and will forward them in the next mail. I think this is a suitable time to have this work done because labour can be got cheap, 35 cents an hour for the man and 30 cents an hour for the young man. It might be necessary to have another man but his wages would be 30 cents an hour.

I will give an estimate of the time I think it will take to get this work done, when I get the prices of the lumber and the nails. I would strongly recommend that this work be done at the present time as it can be done much cheaper now than later on.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant.

The Secretary

Sir,

I have to report that after tearing up the floor in the school house I found that all the joints were rotten under the teacher's house. There is nothing left for me to do but tear up the flooring under the teacher's house and put new joints in place. It seems to understand why all the joints should not but it appears to me there was not enough air space.

I am making sure there will be lots of air space this time as I have trenches dug two across the building and two lengthwise.

I have put two more men on and will have to say there is no more work to be done about 600 feet of flooring and 6 poles 2 x 8 x 14 I am doing all I can to get this job finished before school opens.

I do not think I can finish the job according to the estimate because of the condition of the joints. Flooring in the teacher's house I will keep all costs down as low as possible and I am giving the job all the time I can spare. It just so happens that the soil...
in my office is on holiday and I find it not easy to attend to the office and look after the field work as well but this job is important and I will stay with it until I am sure no mistakes can happen. I cannot get back to Parry Sound until tomorrow so am sending this letter out tonight so that the Department will understand I am up against something I could not foresee and being there I am doing the best I can to get the work done as good and as cheap as possible.

There will be extra for labour and lumber but I will keep it as close to the estimate as possible.

I should state that the chimney that the Inspector reported dangerous has been placed into position and a rock foundation built underneath.

Trusting that the Department approves my action in this matter there is no other way I can see and the men I have are cheap and good but I am taking no chances hence I am very keen looking the matters over and seeing the work is done satisfactory.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant

Dear Mr. Daly,

I received some of the requisition that was sent in at Christmas but was very disappointed indeed for some of the most necessary articles were omitted.

For the past three terms I have ordered pie plates and I see once again they are not among the things sent. Also ordered a dozen size patly pan and five yards of heavy cretonne to cover
the couch in the living room. The present cover on the couch is a disgrace! I have ordered this just five times. There was a garbage pail ordered to hold water, as I'm always out of water and you know the well is half a mile from the house. If I had this pail I can always get the children to fill it up, as it holds about four pails of water.

In the school requisition there was no liftel or dustpan sent, things also very necessary. I really cannot understand this as all things ordered are needed. I do not order things unless they are needed and consequently expect
to get them.

Hoping you will give
this your immediate consider-
ation I am,

Yours sincerely,
Gertrude E. O'Mara
The Secretary,

Ottawa, Ont.,

Sir,

Enclosed please find correspondence received from Miss Gertrude E. O'Meara, School Teacher at the Magnetawan Indian Day School, Bing Inlet, C.P.R. Ont. I am sending the correspondence along to the Department so that they will know just how the teachers feel when their requisitions are not supplied.

The part of the requisition that was sent forward was 5 bars of soap, 1 wash basin, 1 pail, 2 lamp burners, 2 yds of lamp wicking, and 2 tons of coal.

I am writing to Miss O'Meara informing her that the Department at Ottawa has the say as to what part of the requisition will be supplied for the teacher's house.

After reading Miss O'Meara's letter will the Department please say if they can do anything about sending the supplies as ordered through the requisition. I am afraid Miss O'Meara thinks that I am refusing to supply the things she asks for.

The consideration of the Department at their earliest will be very much appreciated.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, enclosing a communication which you received from the teacher of the Magnetawan Indian Day School, regarding the non-receipt by her of supplies for which she requisitioned on December 21st, last. In this connection I have to say that in official letter to you, dated December 30th, you were authorized to purchase the following:

5 bars of soap, 2 lamp burners,
1 wash basin, 2 yards lamp wicking,
1 pail, 2 tons of coal,

for the teacher's residence. It may be that you did not receive this letter. I would request that you arrange for the purchase of the above supplies and have them delivered at the school as soon as possible. Please obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost, which you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment.

Besides the above mentioned articles, it is noted in the teacher's letter that she requests pie plates, a dozen size patty pan and 5 yards of heavy cretonne to cover the couch in the living room, a garbage pail, a stove lifter and a dustpan. Your obedient servant,

EXTRACT FROM INSPECTOR J. M. BENNETT'S REPORT ON THE MAGANETAWAN INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

Date of Inspection - October 10, 1934.

I suppose it is useless to ask for storm windows on the 5 classroom windows. They face the west and get the full force of the cold weather.

Schoolhouse bell needs fixing - the revolving wheel is off and it is a man's job to fix it. It is also badly cracked. There is no sound to it.

School porch is falling away from the building and is leaking badly.
Ottawa, October 30, 1934.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Magnetawan Indian Day School, recommends that storm windows be installed on five classroom windows. He states these windows face the west and are exposed to the full force of the cold weather. He states, further, that repairs are required to the bell - the revolving wheel is off and it is also badly cracked. He states, also, that the school porch is falling away from the building and is leaking badly.

I shall be pleased to have a report from you, regarding the need for storm windows and the approximate cost and also the cost of the repairs required to the bell and school porch.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary

J. M. Daly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Parry Sound, Ont.
Parry Sound, Ont.,
November 1, 1934,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario,

Sir;

Replying to yours of October 30th, 22-8-5, re public school inspector's report of his recent visit of inspection to the Magnetawan Indian Day School, I expect to be up at Magnetawan School in a day or so, and will look the situation over.

The teacher has been asking me for storm windows for the last two years. I explained to the teacher, the lack of funds, but who wants the windows. Re the bell being cracked, that is the first I knew about it. As for the porch falling away from the building and leaking badly, I knew about the porch being a little heaved, but I do not think it is half as bad as he has reported. If so, it has happened in the last two months.

The school would be much more comfortable if we had storm windows, but if we cannot get them there is no reason why the school cannot be kept comfortable, as it is. However, I will report on the situation by the end of the week.

Trusting this will be satisfactory in the meantime.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

JMD/ek.

Mrs. M. Daly,
Parry Sound, Ont.
Dear Mrs. Daly:

Received on Saturday a steel lining for favorite stove. This has to be returned as it is not what ordered. I ordered brick grates for the stove and will look for same in exchange for this lining.

I am still waiting for the six bars of lifeboat soap and 6 soup plates as ordered. Would like to know why such necessary articles as a can opener, butcher knife and bed spread are not being sent. These can all be purchased for about two dollars. I am
surprised at the Dept. cancelling such a trivial amount. There is a bed spread here that has been here since the school was built eight years ago. I am afraid to wash it for fear it falls to pieces.

Has any provision been made for the shipment of the three tons of coal? There is not a bit left from last year and in fact I did not have enough to see the winter through. Hoping this will be looked after before the cold weather sets in; for I froze for two months last year before the coal was delivered.

Trusting you will look after these affairs.

Yours truly,

Gertrude E. O'Meara
Sir:

Replying to yours of October 30th,
28-8-5, re the Public School Inspector's report
of the Magnetawan Indian Day School, and the need
for storm windows, I have been to the Magnetawan
School, and made an inspection, and would recommend
that storm windows be supplied. Following are
the prices received here for the school windows,-
For schoolroom:
5 windows 6'7½" x 2'10½" (6 lights) @ 4.50 - $22.50
For cloak room:
2 windows 6½' x 2½' (4 lights) @ 2.76 - $5.50

Freight on storm windows to Byng Inlet (approx.) 1.00
Cartage from Byng Inlet Station to School " 1.00
Fitting storm windows on. " 2.00

Total:- $32.00

Re the bell, it has been cracked for some
considerable time, but still gives out enough sound to
call the children, all that is required for the wheel
is two screws which I can get here in town.

The school porch is the same as it was the
last time I was there, and I cannot see why the
Inspector should say it was leaking badly. It is not
leaking at all. The last time I was there I instructed
the caretaker to put a strip on the floor opposite the
door. This he has done and I cannot see why it cannot
last in this condition for a number of years. I would
not advise that anything be done to the porch at the
present time.
Owing to the vents being put in the foundation during the last repairs the cold will get in the floor, and this might make the floor a little colder. It is a double floor with heavy building paper between.

My observation since I came here, is that when a teacher has put in three years in the schools in this section that it is time for a change.

The soup plates granted to Miss O'Meara on her last requisition were supplied to her. I sent up two nice soup plates, but they do not match the plates she has and she sent them back with me. I am trying to have the plates matched up with the dishes she has. The brick that she ordered for the stove was not required. It is little fussy things like this that show how the wind is blowing and how for the teacher's benefit she should have a change.

Mr. Moore the School Inspector here informs me that there are 600 qualified teachers in Ontario who would be glad to get a job. I think Miss O'Meara is a good girl, but too long in the one position. I have heard that she does not intend to teach after next June. Miss O'Toole, whom the Department sent to Christian Island, must have heard the same because she has written to me asking me if, when the school becomes vacant and Miss O'Meara leaves she get first consideration for the school. Miss O'Toole's home is about two miles from the school at Britt, across the river.

Re the coal for Miss O'Meara, she has a very hazy idea of costs and thinks her demands should be attended to right away. I tried to explain to her last night, when she suggested that we could get the coal by freight that it would cost too much for loading the coal unloading it, and hauling it to the Reserve. This did not seem to worry her in any way, all she wanted was the coal. There is no need for her being cold as she has always had lots of wood, and the coal will be delivered as soon as the ice is strong enough on the river to haul it across.
If Miss O'Meara were a man, I would say she was "bushed" and would be improved by having a change from Magnetawan Reserve. Enclosed please find a letter sent to me by Miss O'Meara.

I explained to Miss O'Meara that the coal would be delivered to her as soon as the ice was strong enough to stand the transportation of it across the river. It is a short distance across the river to Britt, but it would cost almost as much as the price of the coal to have it sent by freight, because of the handling.

As Miss O'Meara is impatient about getting the storm windows would the Department please reply at their earliest.

Trusting this is the information required.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Agent.

JMD/EK.

Ottawa, November 8, 1934.

Sir:

I have your letter of the third instant, with reference to the supplying of storm windows for use on the classroom and cloakroom windows at the Magnetawan Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of you incurring an expenditure of approximately $32.00 in supplying the windows, of the dimensions required, and having them shipped to the school. Please forward an account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred. You should attach receipts for the freight and cartage charges.

In view of your report, the Department is not prepared to authorize any expenditure in connection with the bell or the school porch.

Regarding the supplying of the coal, it is noted that you will have this delivered as soon as the ice is strong enough to stand the transportation of it across. In the meantime, the teacher can use wood for heating purposes.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. M. Daly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Parry Sound,
Ont.

Extract from Inspector Bennett's report on the Magnetawan Indian Day School visited on May 20, 1941.

RECOMMENDATIONS:

1. Toilets need repairing. In the wind storm last fall they were blown over.

2. The front porch is pulling away from the building. This school was built in low-lying land. Water remains under it even in the summertime. It will never be right until it is moved to higher ground.
Ottawa,
July 4, 1941.

Dear Sir:

In reporting on his inspection of the Magnetawan Indian Day School on May 20 Inspector Bennett writes:

"Toilets need repairing. In the wind storm last fall they were blown over.

"The front porch is pulling away from the building. This school was built in low-lying land. Water remains under it even in the summertime. It will never be right until it is moved to higher ground."

I am aware of conditions at this school and I presume that it would be difficult to make any permanent improvement without spending a very large sum of money which, at the present moment, is not available.

However, I should appreciate receiving another report from you regarding this building indicating what improvements you consider might be made.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. S. Devlin,
Indian Agent,
Parry Sound, Ont.
Parry Sound, Ont.,
July 8, 1941.

Dear Sir:

Reference: Letter, July 4, 22-8-5.

I am in receipt of the above letter re the condition of the Magnetawan Indian Day School. There is no doubt that, due to the selection of a poor site when this school was built, it requires repairs and adjustments practically every year. However, I think that the repairs made to it last year will hold it for some little time without any major expenditure. There are some things which can be done this year and which I plan to have done during the summer holidays and will advise you later as to the extent and probable cost of the repairs.

Yours truly,

Samuel Devlin,

Both toilets are so placed in low land that in wet weather it is difficult to approach them, as I found out, without getting one's feet wet. One of the toilets needs cleaning. Ottawa,

Dear Sir:

In reporting on his recent inspection of the Magnetawan Indian Day School, Inspector Bennett writes:

"Both toilets are so placed in low land that in wet weather it is difficult to approach them, as I found out, without getting one's feet wet. One of the toilets needs cleaning. (Urgent) The gates are off the fence enclosing the property. The roofs are leaking in the porch and pupils' cloakroom. So is the woodshed roof. This teacher is not residing here now, boards elsewhere. Night prowlers had made living conditions rather trying on the nerves."

We are aware of the condition of this building but funds are not available for extensive improvements or replacement. However, there are funds available for repairs and you might let me know the approximate cost of making the improvements suggested in the Inspector's report.

Yours truly,

Mr. S. Devlin, Indian Agent, Parry Sound, Ont.

In reporting on his inspection of the Magnetawan School Inspector Bennett writes as follows:

"Boys' toilet so insecurely set up that it has been blown over by strong winds. Couldn't these toilets be set on higher grounds? Every spring when I come they are surrounded with water.

"School house needs painting inside and outside. The classroom is not very attractive inside."

Please let me have an estimate of the cost of painting the interior of this school.

It is difficult to understand why something could not be done to the toilets. I wrote to you along similar lines in a letter dated June 15, 1942, to which you did not reply. I should appreciate your giving immediate consideration to the matter and letting me know what can be done.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

File No. 22-8-5.

Acknowledging receipt of your letter of the 3rd Inst., I beg to submit the following with regard to the situation at the Magnetawan School.

I inspected the toilets there last summer and had any necessary work done. The site chosen for this school in the first place was not ideal, but I cannot see that there can be very much done about it now. The site of the school and its surroundings are low ground and in wet weather it does get very muddy. I will have in mind the situation of the toilets and will see if it is possible to have these moved to a more suitable location.

With regard to painting the school house, I would not recommend this at this time as, in my opinion, the building does not require this for several years at least. I have seen schoolhouses throughout the country which have a much worse appearance than our school on the Magnetawan Reserve.

You will observe that following your letter of June last I had all the work that was necessary done on the toilets.

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

On November 20, 1942 authority was granted, File No. 22-8-5, for repairs to the Magnetawan Indian Day School, which involved principally the building of a cement chimney on the teacher's residence. The chimney was purchased and shipped to the school, but I was unable to get the work done before winter set in and had to put off the job until now. As the man I was relying on has now left that neighborhood, I will be obliged to send a man from town to do the work. I find also that I was misled as to the number of cement blocks necessary to build the chimney and that I will require about eight more sections. A recent inspection also reveals some other small items of repairs and the revised bill will be as follows:

Ottawa, June 1st, 1927.

Sir,-

The Department understands that all the Indians of the Maganetawan band are Roman Catholics (Reference your letter of June 13th, 1926), and there is a Catholic teacher at this school.

I note that the school has been inspected by the Public School Inspector. It is our practice to have Roman Catholic schools inspected by Separate School Inspectors, and I should be pleased if you would inform me whether there is any reason why the same procedure should not be followed at Maganetawan as at other Catholic Indian schools.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

J.M. Daly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Parry Sound, Ont.
Parry Sound, Ont.,
June 14, 1927.

The Secretary,
Dept. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

Replying to yours of June 1, 22-816, re--inspection of Maganetawan Indian Day School, I should state that there is no reason that I know of why this school should not be inspected by a separate school inspector, in fact, I should rather like it for my teacher there would be liable to get more credit for her work.

Perhaps it is not known to the Dept. but it is a fact that all the teachers in this Agency are asked by me to take an interest in the spiritual welfare of the children and in justice to the teachers, I must say they all do. I have arranged with the Parish Priest to supply catechisms and with the teachers to take sufficient time to instruct the children in same. The same applies to the Protestant children. I really think it would be the proper thing to have this school inspected by a separate school inspector.

Trusting that this is the information required,

I have the honour to be.

Sir:
Your obedient servant,

Agent.

JMD/RD
Ottawa, June 8th, 1927.

Sir,-

As the teacher and pupils of the Maganetawan Indian Day School are Roman Catholics, it is desired that this school be inspected, in future, by a Separate School Inspector.

It has previously been inspected by Mr. J.L. Moore, Public School Inspector, Parry Sound, Ontario. Please advise him that it will not be necessary for him to visit this school in future. I would also appreciate if you would arrange to have it inspected by Mr. J.M. Bennett. His first visit to the school should be made during the Fall term as Mr. Moore has inspected this school on April 8th last.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Schools.— The Manitou Indians inform me that they wish to have their school re-opened, and to have Mr. Robert Gill, appointed as teacher, he taught this school in 1888, he understands their language and the whole band wish to have him as their teacher. I understand he taught school in England, and I would strongly recommend that he be appointed, as I think he will get a good attendance. I informed the Indians that unless they would guarantee an average attendance of at least eight pupils, I would not recommend the school to be opened, this they have promised to do, but they say that they do not want Mr. Fryer to have anything to do with their teacher or school, for if he did he would want to have their children taught religion, and they claim that is what broke up their school before, the teacher wanting to teach them religion. All the Indians of this band are pagans. They say that they never asked to have a big school on the Rainy River, they say Mr. Fryer made that up himself.
Ottawa, October 8th, 1909.

Sir,

Mr. Robert Gill may be appointed as their teacher provisionally. His retention in office to depend on the manner in which the school is conducted, and an average of eight being maintained.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Secretary.

REPORT OF INSPECTOR SEMMENS ON THE MANITOU RAPIDS DAY SCHOOL.

The number on the roll during the quarter which preceded the summer holidays was 35 or 17 boys and 18 girls. The average attendance for the same period was 15 which was only fair considering the number of families brought together by the amalgamation of the Bands.

Since the holidays the number has been smaller still. At the time of my visit there were 11 boys and 5 girls present which was slightly above the present average, two boys being noted as visitors on this occasion.

The examination of the classes was fairly satisfactory. Reading was good considering the short time which has elapsed since teaching was begun. Spelling was fair and writing was good. One or two of the boys show considerable ability in drawing. Behaviour in school appeared very good but the teacher reported that the boys were rather rough in their treatment of the girls out of doors and that all pupils seemed to regard all milder forms of punishment with stolid indifference.

Evelyn Alderson

Attended Barwick Consolidated School about two
years after passing High School Entrance - Only

Success not good, but fair considering teacher's

It may be difficult to secure a qualified teacher
but no real success can be expected till a
qualified teacher who is a real teacher possessing
considerable tact and judgment be placed in charge
of the school.

Too great and rapid improvement cannot be expected
but some should surely be made. The great hindrance
is the home-life of the children.

A real live and suitable teacher could, no doubt,
work wonders in the school but the difficulty is to
induce such a teacher to accept the principalship
of an Indian School.

Pagan. This is my first inspection of this school
and I have endeavoured to confine myself to general
conditions and advancement of pupils, but at the
next visit I shall be able to give an account of the
progress made. I am confident proper inspection of the

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Manitou Rapids Indian Day School, has drawn attention to the work being performed by Evelyn E. Alderson in the classroom. He states she has no professional qualifications and that the success being achieved in the work is not good. He also states that no real success can be expected until a qualified teacher, possessing tact and judgment, is placed in charge of the school, and that a real live and suitable teacher could, no doubt, work wonders in the school.

When Miss Alderson was engaged, it was on the understanding that her services, if not satisfactory, would be dispensed with at the end of the present school year, viz., June 30th, next. The Department would be prepared to pay a higher salary if the services of a teacher having second class professional qualifications were secured. You should, in due time, endeavour to nominate the services of a qualified teacher for this school for the next school year, stating the name, qualifications and experience of the teacher whom you recommend for the position. When we have this information, consideration will then be given to the rate of salary we can allow. When replying, you should also furnish full information as to the boarding accommodation available for a teacher.

Please inform Miss Alderson in due time that her services will not be required after the end of the present school year.

Your obedient servant,

Mr. Russell Maclean,

Dear sir,

I have commenced my work at the Manitou Rapids School and expect to like it very much. However I have a request to make. Would it be possible for me to get my cheque every month instead of quarterly. I am not asking this idly as there is real necessity for it. I am financing my brother and sister in college and they have heavy fees to pay before I should have anything to send them if I didn't get my salary monthly.

I hope you will be able to arrange this as it would relieve my mind considerably.

Sincerely,

Florence E. Elford.

Madam,

With reference to your letter of the 8th instant, I beg to say that the salaries of teachers of Indian day schools are paid quarterly on the basis of ten teaching months in the school year.

The Department is prepared, however, when funds are available, to allow an advance on salary. Payment of such advance will be made to you on receipt of application through the office of your local Indian Agent.

Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 16th ultimo; in which you have drawn my attention to two items that have been duplicated in account, for scrubbing of Manitou Rapids Indian Day School. And as requested enclosed you will find Deposit Receipt and Draft, in favor of the Receiver General of Canada, for the sum of $3.75, refund for overpayment of account for scrubbing of the Manitou School.

Mr Hayes, the Farm Instructor of Manitou Reserve, has always been paying for the scrubbing of the school, getting Receipt for same and sending them on to me for to be forwarded to the Department for payment. In this I had done the same as in the past, took his Receipts made out Account and forwarded it to the Department, not knowing that he had taken a Receipt from Mrs Medicine and given her an order on Langstaff Co for $25, and they in turn charged it up to the Department. No doubt but Hayes intended to pay Langstaff Co, when he received Cheque for scrubbing of School, because as soon as I receive a Cheque for scrubbing I simply sign it and forward it to Mr Hayes, for advance made for scrubbing. In future you may rest assured that I will see that there are no duplicated accounts goes into the Department if I can help it.

I have the honor to be,

Sir.

And in reply to same, I have to report that there is Three Acres of ground in the School Lot, and on this lot there is a combined School and Farm Inst'r Residence, an Implement shed and a stable, there is no separate ground fenced off for the children, and they have access to the whole Three Acres, the Farm Inst'r has a cow and no doubt but the cow grazes on the School lot.

We have a lot of Machinery at the Machinery shed and as the children will not keep away from the machinery, Mrs Hayes tries to keep them away, and for this reason the Indians are very sore at her.

There is a little fault on both sides, Mrs Hayes has no place to hang her clothes when she washes, and the children run all amongst her clothes, because she has to hang them in the school yard, and she gets very angry at them, and when she scolds them they go home and tell their parents.

To save all this trouble, I would recommend that a portion of this Ground be fenced off for the School Children, so that the children would know where they should be, as we cannot have them fooling with machinery and around the stable, as it is so late this fall, it could not be done, but it should be done the first thing in the spring, and by doing this I think we could avoid all trouble between the parents and Mrs Hayes.

The steps leading to the Classroom should be repaired or new steps built, as the wood in the steps are practically decayed beyond repair. Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his inspection of the Manitou Rapids Indian Day School on October 13th, last, draws attention to the condition of the steps leading to the classroom. He recommends that they be repaired or new ones built. He states the wood in the steps is practically decayed beyond repair and that the steps are really not safe.

I have therefore to request that you will arrange to have these steps repaired and placed in a good, strong condition, at the earliest possible date. Sir;

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 22nd:- in regard to supplying midday meals for the Manitou Rapids Day School.

In reply to the same I have to report that on August 6th., 1933, letter No. 124-3-5, I was authorized to purchase cocoa and milk for midday meals at the Manitou Day School. Since that date the School children have been receiving a midday meal consisting of biscuits and cocoa, and as I was never requested to cease doing so the children have been receiving these meals at noon.

The children at the Manitou School have a long way to come to School, some as far as three miles. Often when there is nothing to eat at home their only meal is the biscuits and cocoa received at the school. It is hard to state how long the cocoa and milk will last, as it all depends on how many children attend School. The last purchase was on February 3rd. 1933, but the present purchase should last for about six months.

I may have been at fault for not sending in a Requisition for purchase of these articles, but I was not aware of the purchase of the same until I received the bill. The Teacher notified the Farm Instructor that they were out of cocoa and milk for the midday meal and he at once purchased the cocoa and milk for the School.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

I have the honour to report that the Kaniqou Rapids Indian Day School furnace is in very bad condition. It is cracked so badly that they are smoked out when a fire is put on in the furnace.

I have seen Mr. Tompkins of Emo, Ontario and he informs me that it can be fixed by taking it out and patching the crack but it would only crack again. This is because all the cold air goes in on the one side of the furnace and to stop it from cracking there would have to be two cold air pipes put in on the other side of the furnace which would cost about $100.00.

I would requisition the Department for authority to have this alteration done so the School could be heated to better advantage. Mr. Tompkins claims that it would be a saving on fuel and the School could be heated not matter what direction the wind blows. At present it cannot be heated when the wind is from the west.

I have the honour to be,

Sir.

Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 13th of May, 1935, in regard to repair to Indian Day School as recommended by Inspector Hamilton.

And as requested by your letter, you will find estimate for the porches of the School, the estimate is $52.76.

In regard to the Furnace of the School, we repaired this Furnace last fall, which was of some help, but the furnace is so badly cracked that it cannot be repaired, and will need a new furnace, the estimates you will find enclosed.

The Calsomining of the interior of the School, and the painting of the ceiling would cost $50.00, that is the estimate I receive from Mr Prior of Emo, Ont. This School should be re-decorated as it is very dirty, and has not been calsomined since it was built 20 Years Ago.

I would recommend that this work be done during vacation so that it would not disturb the School work.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, June 29, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 21st instant, regarding the repairs and the new furnace required at the Manitou Rapids Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that you may incur an expenditure, to the amount of $52.76 - the estimate which you submitted - in supplying the materials and labour for the purpose of repairing the front steps and porches of the school. You may also incur an expenditure, not exceeding the sum of $60.00, in kalsomining the interior of the school and painting the ceiling.

Further, the Department will approve of the installation of a new furnace, and you may place the order with the Wells Hardware Company, Limited, to move the old furnace, and to set up a new cast iron furnace, of a suitable size; reset the brick-work, putting in new brick where necessary and cover the two hot air pipes in the wood-room with asbestos covering, for the amount quoted by them, viz.: $176.00.

I enclose encumbrance certificate, providing an amount of $280 for the purpose of carrying out the above mentioned repairs and for supplying and installing the new furnace. The work should be done during the coming summer holidays, and, when completed to your satisfaction, you should forward itemized accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of the materials, and accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred in the labour. You should state definitely the number of days or hours employed and the rate paid. Please state, on each copy of the voucher, that the expenditure was incurred under authority of E. R. No. 3409.

Your obedient servant,

Secretary.

Ottawa, Oct. 5, 1923.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant, with reference to the request of the Rev. Father Hogan for an increase in the grant, paid by this Department for the tuition of the Indian children who attend the Mattawa Separate School.

In reply I beg to say that the Department is under no obligation for the education of the half-breed children. We note that the majority of the half-breed families reside in the town of Mattawa and are assessed and pay school taxes. As there are only 12 bona fide Indian children who attend regularly, and in view of the excellent reports received, regarding the work of this school, the Department will allow an increase of $100 per annum in the grant, from the first of September, last, the beginning of the present school year. This will make the grant allowed from that date at the rate of $350 per annum, which is considered ample remuneration for the number of Indian children who attend. I shall be pleased if you will inform the Rev. Father Hogan and the school authorities accordingly.

In preparing the quarterly returns, only the names of the bona fide Indian children who attend should be included and no half-breed children should be mentioned.

At the end of June, last, Mrs. Catherine Bernard called at the Department to see if some of her grandchildren, whose fathers are dead, could be placed in an industrial or boarding school.

Ottawa, Oct. 5, 1923.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant, with reference to the request of the Rev. Father Hogan for an increase in the grant, paid by this Department for the tuition of the Indian children who attend the Mattawa Separate School.

In reply I beg to say that the Department is under no obligation for the education of the half-breed children. We note that the majority of the half-breed families reside in the town of Mattawa and are assessed and pay school taxes. As there are only 12 bona fide Indian children who attend regularly, and in view of the excellent reports received, regarding the work of this school, the Department will allow an increase of $100 per annum in the grant, from the first of September, last, the beginning of the present school year. This will make the grant allowed from that date at the rate of $350 per annum, which is considered ample remuneration for the number of Indian children who attend. I shall be pleased if you will inform the Rev. Father Hogan and the school authorities accordingly.

In preparing the quarterly returns, only the names of the bona fide Indian children who attend should be included and no half-breed children should be mentioned.

Ottawa, 20th October, 1902-

To the Asst. Secretary-

A School building erected in accordance with the sketch forwarded with Agent Hodder's letter of the 14th Instant, would be expensive and unsightly. It would also be difficult and expensive to keep it warm. I think it altogether objectionable, and would advise that it be not approved.

A two story building giving the same space, could have a very pleasing outward appearance, and be commodiously arranged inside. The cost of erection would be at least one fifth less, and the heating arrangement would involve less immediate and future expense. The cost of such a building should not exceed $2600.00. That is to say, it is to be a frame building erected on a stone foundation.

It is proposed that the building should be heated with a wood furnace. This involves the construction of a furnace pit, and necessarily a drain therefrom. The point should be settled whether the site on which the building is to be erected is a favourable one for the construction of a drain.

In the event of it being so, I would recommend that as the extra cost would not be very great (less than $200.00) that the entire basement be excavated. This will add to the warmth of the building, a room for the storage of wood, and a play room for the boys, besides the
the necessary furnace room.

With regard to preparing Plans and Specifications I beg to state that I would be glad to prepare them in my Office, as we have occasionally done heretofore, but we have so much work on hand that we positively cannot undertake this, without dropping other work equally urgent.

In addition to the foregoing, an Architect residing at or near the place, would be more competent because better locally informed, to draw up the Plans and Specifications for a suitable building. In any case, if the Plans and Specifications were made here, it would be desirable to employ a local Architect to oversee the work. I therefore beg to recommend that a local Architect be employed to get up the necessary Plans and Specifications, and to superintend the work.

Chief Surveyor-

OTTAWA, 31st December, 1902

The Deputy Superintendent General:-

Re proposed erection of a new schoolhouse on the Fort William Reserve.

Mr Separate School Inspector Prendergast in his report on the Fort William schools made in May last called the Department's attention to the lack of proper accommodation, stating that the building was old and not in good repair and that the room for the younger pupils was too small for the attendance. He strongly recommended the erection of a new building without delay as it would be poor economy to patch up so unsuitable a building as the old one. (Report on 153815----6 herewith)

In addition to the day pupils on the reserve who are attending this school, the children from the Orphanage are also taught there, all being classified together as a graded school with two teachers. There are about 70 children of school age on the reserve, and 36 in the Orphanage, and of these 72 are enrolled with an average attendance of 47 for last year.

Mr Agent Hodder's attention was called to the Inspector's remarks and he was asked for a report thereon making suggestions as to any improvements he thought might be made. He replied stating that the building is not large enough for the present attendance and is in a very bad state of repair, and that in his opinion it would be advisable to erect a new one. A resolution was passed by the Band for the erection of a modern school building to be paid for out.
out of their funds. A sketch of the building it was proposed to put up was forwarded, which provided for a one-story structure but no estimate of the cost was given. The Department informed the Agent that it was considered a two-story building would be more suitable and economical and asked him to furnish a rough estimate of the probable cost, as such information was required before a memorandum could be submitted to Council.

The Agent now forwards a resolution of the Band asking that the sum of $5000.00 be set aside from their funds for a new schoolhouse, which they would prefer to have built of stone.

As the capital funds of the Band are less than $9000.00 I think it would be well to have a report from the Accountant before submitting the matter to Council as a stone building such as they want would, when finished and properly equipped, leave a very small balance to their credit.

It is some years since I saw the present building when then appeared to be substantial and capable of enlargement. The Mission buildings are all first class stone structures and it is no doubt the desire of the missionary and the Indians to have a school in keeping with them.

Memorandum:-

At the conclusion of the annuity payments at Fort William I visited the Indian Day School, which, however, was not then in session.

With regard to the school building I desire to report that it is in a very bad condition. The building is a frame one and the outside boards are so rotten in many places that they will not hold together. The foundation also has given way so that the building has sunk and in consequence there are large openings at the tops of the doors which must let in a great deal of cold in winter. The floors too are badly worn, and, in fact, the whole building is, in my opinion, unfit for use as a school.

In addition to the fact that the building is in such a bad state of repair I have also to say that it is altogether too small to accommodate the number of pupils, between 70 and 80, who attend.

The seats are so close together that it must be very uncomfortable for the children to sit in them. The box-stove also which is used to heat the building almost fills up the width of the hall and must add to the discomfort of the pupils whose seats are in its vicinity.
