OTTAWA, 22nd September, 1904:

The Deputy Superintendent General:

The day school building on the Ft. William reserve is in very bad condition and from reports received from the Agent, the Inspector and Mr Stewart of this Department (who was lately there) it would appear that a new building is absolutely necessary.

The Ft. William Band two years ago wished to expend the sum of $5000.00 out of their capital funds for the purpose of providing a new schoolhouse. The Accountant pointed out in his memo. of 5th Jan. 1903, that their capital would not stand this outlay as they had only about $9,000.00 to their credit, which produced a revenue of a little less than $300.00.

Mr Agent Bonin who was lately asked to furnish an estimate for a new wooden building, instead of one of stone, and he states that, with a stone foundation and suitable basement, it would cost $2,650.00 and without a basement $2,000.00. He says that the Indians are now not satisfied to take even this amount from their capital, claiming that a number of the children who attend this school come from other Bands.

There is no doubt that a new schoolhouse is required. The children in the Orphanage all attend this school which has also to provide for the day pupils on the reserve and it is just a question of how much the band should be asked to contribute. I
would certainly recommend that the building have a basement and stone foundation. Mr. Scott informs me that the Band is not in a position to contribute anything and that the money will have to be voted. This will entail a delay of a year at least.

The Fort William Orphanage is a very useful institution, and is the only Roman Catholic School between Rat Portage and Wikwemikong, while the Indians between these points are Roman Catholic with a few exceptions.

Sir,

As I have lately visited the school house on the Indian Reserve at Fort William, Ontario, desire to place before you after facts to show the necessity of providing a new building. The present building which is of wood, is so long built and the walls and joints are so decayed that it would be too costly to repair. Last winter there was an epidemic of typhoid fever amongst the children so much so that the Sisters were obliged to close the school and send the boarders home to their parents. Your obedient servant

Dear Sir:

Another point that requires the attention of the Dept. is the building of the new schools, one for the Indians at Squaw Bay and another one, I suppose, will be provided for the Indians established at the Mountain. Rev. Sir,

In further reference to the proposed establishment of day schools for the Fort William band at their new locations I beg to say that, after April 1, next, the beginning of the new fiscal year, the grant now paid to the two teachers at the Fort William Orphanage will cease, and the money now voted for these teachers will be paid to the teachers of the day schools at Squaw Bay and the Mountain when established.

As there is a temporary school in operation at present at Squaw Bay, one teacher's salary only will be paid at Fort William and this will be continued at Squaw Bay, and if a school is established at the Mountain, the other salary will be used to pay a teacher there.

In boarding schools under the per capita grant system no allowance is made for teachers' salaries, and the Department's only reason for continuing the grant is that day pupils are in attendance and it is willing to allow the salary of one teacher for instructing these pupils.

The Mission, Fort William, Aug. 12th, 1907

The Secretary, Dept. of Ind. Affairs,

Dear Sir,

I see that the schools to be built at Mission Bay and at the Mountain for the Indians of this Reserve will not be ready for opening at the usual time. Will this delay affect the salary of the teachers?

I had secured the services of a teacher early in June for the Mountain school. She would have accepted another position if she thought that the salary would be less than $300.00.

I would like to have an answer from the Dept. about the salary before I make any agreement for the Mission Bay school.

The Indians of that place would like to have a man teacher, but we could not get a man teacher for the ordinary salary of $300.00.

She may obtain help, if none of the ladies who conducted the Waskwemikong Girls' school, if the Sisters of Saint Joseph do not decide after all to build at Mission Bay, but I could not say when we could obtain those ladies.

I met Mr. Ogilvie, architect of the Dept., last week at Mission Bay and he told me that a separate
house from the school is to be built for the teacher's accommodation. And the school is to be heated by a furnace, according to a law passed by the Government. But we cannot expect a girl teacher to attend to the furnace; and this will mean a double quantity of fuel at both places.

Your humble servant,

Rev. C. Laverdière

Dear Sir:

I would like to get an answer to that part of my last letter of August 12th., inquiring about the salary of the teachers for the new schools to be built very soon, I hope, at Mission Bay and at the Mountain Road for the Indians of those two places. I wanted to know if the salaries of the teachers would be diminished on account of the delay to build the schools. I received an answer but not to the purpose. Early in June I retained the services of one teacher for the Mountain school, and she refused an offer of $300.00 with boarding for the Wikwemikong Girls' school, because she preferred to remain near her sister at Fort William, if the salary was the same, viz: $300.00. I have to look for another teacher for the Mission Bay and would like to know what salary can be offered for the rest of the year.

I think that it would be hard to obtain a teacher for less than $300.00, even considering that the first quarter will soon be over.

Your very humble servant in Xst,

Dear Sir,

In a letter addressed to the Indian Agent by you I see that the Department desires to have further information in regard to the qualifications of Mr. Jerry Hila for the position of school teacher at Mission Bay. First I must say that if I had not known the man to be well qualified for the position I would not have recommended him, for if any one is anxious to have a competent school teacher for the children of this mission you may be sure that I am very anxious to have a good school teacher if possible.

Now I must say that Mr. J. Hila holds no school teachers certificate, but that he has made a complete commercial course of studies in one of the best schools in Quebec, moreover he has been for two years in the employ of the Canadian Pacific Railway Co. as book keeper & otherwise in offices. I beg to say that you may have all the references needed from the following C.P.R. officers: James Campbell, Cashier on Selkirk division, A. G. McCall, Chief accountant.
at White River), W. B. Way, train master at White River, J. S. Kent chief clerk to the Superintendent also at White River and C. S. Rogers, C.P.R. agent, White River.

Besides these men, who could give recommendations as to the capacity of Mr. Alice, I have to say that I know him personally for nearly three years, and from that can judge I am positive that Mr. Alice is far better qualified to fill the position of school teacher than any of those who have heretofore been appointed by the Department to be teachers in any of the Indian schools or the numerous missions that I was in charge of for over nine years.

I hope Mr. the Secretary that this will be enough to induce the Dept. to place Mr. Alice in charge of this school notwithstanding what the Indians may have or may write contrary to my statement. I humbly think that I am a better judge than them in the matter.

I send this letter directly to the Dept. because I am afraid the Agent neglects to do so, and can tell by the dates on the letters received by him from the Dept. I wrote to him first on 25th January, and I see on your letter that he only forwarded my letter on the 27th Feb., since then I went four times to Port Arthur to see, but could never find him in his office.

Your humble servant,

Dear Sir,

In reply to your of the 15th just received, I beg to say that I recommend Mr. Jerry Alan for the position of school teacher at Mission Bay, because I know him personally for nearly three years, moreover I know that he made a good commercial course of studies in one of the best commercial college in Quebec. So the man was working for us last winter. I tried to induce him to teach school here, for a long time he refused but at last consented to accept the position, it is then that I recommended him because I am very anxious to have the best teacher possible for our school, and I think it would be hard to find anyone better qualified for the position than he is.

Mr. Alan has been for two years in the employ of the C.P.R. as book keeper and other wise in offices. You may have all the references needed from the following offices: James Coughlan, Roadmaster, Schreiber; A. J. McColl, chief accountant at White River; W. B. Way, train master White River; E. E. Hart, city clerk to the Superintendent White River, and also E. B. Beeson, post master White River. By these you can see that Mr. Alan...
is well known by people who can judge of his capacity as a scholar, far better than some Indians who may write or have written contrary to my statement.

As to the school at the foot of the mountain, I do not see any need of opening before the sisters close their own school, but I would like to have Dominic Ducharme appointed for that school so that he could begin to teach as soon as the sisters close their school. No matter what the old Bible says I am afraid that there will be very few children attending that school, and I say that because experience of nine years has taught me that nearly none of the children now residing at the Mountain have ever attended school, but I am very willing to give them a fair trial and if they were to go to school I will be very, very glad.

Please Mr. Agent, try to have Mr. Ducharme appointed for Mission Bay school as soon as possible, at the same time he will continue to teach and I will pay him myself if the Agent refuses, which I am sure the Agent will not do.

Your humble servant,

L.V. Ducey

Mission Bay, Fort William August 8th 1908

Mr. W. Lea
Dept. Indian Affairs.

Dear Sir,

Mme Ducharme has been teaching school on the mountain road for a month by the order of Mr. Macdonald and from the 14th of June to the 27th June here at this Bay also with the approval of the Indian Agent. Mr. Macdonald told Mme Ducharme that he could not be paid for his teaching, that seems to me very strange, when the Agent told Mme Ducharme to teach she promised him that he would be paid alright for his teaching. I wish that you would try to something to have justice done in favor of Mme Ducharme.

On June 12th Mr. Macdonald wrote to me that Mme Ducharme could teach here if I wanted her as the Agent did not approve of the school being open on the mountain road. I had Mme Ducharme to teach here at once, and wrote to Port Arthur to tell Mr. Macdonald, but as usual he was not in his office so I wrote at least seven times to Port Arthur to see your Agent and could never find him. I wrote to him about the 28th of June notifying that Mme Ducharme was teaching here, and to please arrange with the Dept. to have him pay appointed...
but I never had any answer from him. Mr. Doughty went several times to see the school when he was lucky enough to see him. Mr. Doughty always told him to continue teaching, nor the man should be paid by all means.

I wish also to tell the fact that the teacher does not seem to care at all about the school building here at the Bay and on the mountain road near. If those buildings be finished and the chimney in the teacher's house here at the Bay is about to fall down, the bricks are all loose at the back in the cellar. Mr. Doughty will do his very utmost for the Indians should he that those houses be finished and the chimney would at once.

The road from the old mission to here is in a very bad condition. We let the men who were to be willing to do anything to finish the road. As you know we will have to move the crops from the old to the new cemetery this fall, and it is pretty near impossible to carry these crops over a road like the one we have. In the spring the bridges were fixed up the worst, Mr. Doughty had them repaired at last, and always has men to work on the road for days repairing bridges and putting sand over the stones in the way. I wish to say it would cost again at least two or three weeks work to be done in the road here to all that would enable us to transport the crops from the old to the new grave-yard without wrecking everything and the dust would be so bad. Has he promised that next week to the Indians that they would have a good road.

Hoping that you will do your best in that city of our poor Indians, I remain your truly,

[Signature]

This arrangement is, no doubt, feasible, and would save the expense involved in the erection of a new school building.

The Department will, therefore, approve of your suggestion to have the present school residence fitted up for classroom purposes, and you may arrange to have the necessary alterations made to the building. The Department will leave this matter in your hands to carry out the alterations which you consider necessary in order to provide sufficient classroom accommodation. The expenditure involved should not exceed your estimate, namely, $200, and you may arrange with a competent contractor, or the Indians, if they are competent to do the work, to make the necessary alterations.

If any material is required, it will be necessary to obtain competitive prices before the purchase is made, or you may call for tenders, which should include all material and labour, and give the contract to the person quoting you the lowest price.

The accounts, when received, will be paid from the money received for the insurance on the former school building.

Sir:

I beg to report last week the Fort William School Board approached Miss Whelan, teacher of the Mission Bay Indian Day School, Fort William Reserve, to ascertain if she would accept a vacancy in one of their schools. She consulted Dr. Gillie, our Indian physician, who advised her strongly to discontinue the Field Matron's work, and try and get back to teaching. Sir,

In connection with official letter to you, of the 23rd inst., forwarding plans and specifications for the proposed school-house and residences for the Fort William band, to be erected at Squaw Bay and the Mountain village, I have to request that you will at once proceed to these localities and select suitable sites for these buildings.

In looking at the plan of the Squaw Bay village, the point on which the council house is erected would appear to be the most central location for the school for that place, and, if you think it would be convenient to place the residence there, you may do so; or, if not, choose one of the unoccupied lots in the vicinity. The school-house and dwelling, if placed there, should face in the same direction as the council house, but if the residence is to go on one of the village lots, it should face the road.

At the Mountain village, these buildings should be placed on the Government road, if possible, and, if no site is available on this road, as near the centre of the village as space can be obtained. Lot No. 5 appears to be available. This lot is situated on Concession 3 according to Mr. Lügheed's plan.

With reference to the construction of school buildings and teachers' residences at Mission Bay and Mountain Village, Fort William Reserve, I have to say that the Department is not disposed to spend such a large sum of money as that indicated by the tender in the construction of these buildings, unless with the consent of the Indian Council.

Before submitting the matter to the Indian Council please request LeBlonde to give you a tender on school houses, modified as follows:

To be no basement or excavation or furnace. The building is to simply rest on an ordinary stone foundation raised two feet above the ground, to be of the same dimensions as indicated on the plan, but without the steps, of course, at the back. The shed will be required for wood; it should, however, be two feet wider than it is now. The shed is to be of the ordinary type of wood-shed resting on cedar posts. The chimney should be provided with a fire-place, and a thimble placed at a proper distance above for the reception of the stove-pipe. A good box-stove thirty inches long piping and zinc should be provided.

Neil McDougall, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your telegram in reply to mine relating to the construction of teachers' residences and school-houses on the Fort William Indian Reserve and to submit to you herewith agreement, sketches and specifications as arranged between the contractor Mr. G.J. Le Blond and myself.

The principal points of difference between the original plans and specifications and those now agreed upon are the following:

The buildings at the Mountain are a little smaller.
The furnaces are omitted.
The plumbing is omitted in all buildings.
Basements are omitted in the Mountain buildings.
Front porch and cupola to school building omitted.
Ship lap on the interior omitted.

Ottawa
The roof construction is much simpler.
Two coats of paint instead of three coats.

The buildings at Mission Bay are partly constructed and to such an extent that material changes cannot be made; otherwise the construction of buildings that I feel assured you would consider to be quite satisfactory could have been arranged for the sum of six thousand dollars.

At a meeting with ex-chief Penassie and the principal residents at the Mission Village I showed them the sketches of the buildings as now proposed with which they expressed themselves as being quite pleased.

The contractor Mr. C.J. LeBlond is a man of good standing. He has a number of other buildings under construction in Fort William. I think we may rely on having satisfactory work done. He is also

Report of Inspector J.P.Finn on the Mission Bay School.

Buildings,-
The closets are broken. The doors are off and need repairs.

Blackboards,-
Blackboards are very badly needed. One should be placed low enough for the pupils to work on.

Grounds,-
The grounds are rough and stony and could be improved by placing on these stones some fine material either in the way of soil or sand.
Ottawa, May 22, 1914.

Sir,

Mr. Inspector Finn, in his report on the Mission Bay School, states that the closets are broken, that the doors are off and need repairs, that blackboards are very badly needed, that the grounds are rough and stony and could be improved by placing on these stones some fine material either in the way of soil or sand.

You are hereby authorized to have the necessary repairs made to the closets.

The Department would like you to state the dimensions of the blackboards required so that hyloplate can be ordered and also to give an estimate of the probable cost of improving the school grounds.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. Russell Brown, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.

In reply to yours of May 27th file 307515/5 I could say that I visited the Mission Bay school yesterday, and left orders to have the closets refitted.

The blackboard required should be seven feet long and about four high.

It would cost several hundred dollars to level these grounds and cover with sand as they are large and rocky. Yours truly,

OTTAWA, August 8th, 1921.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant informing the Department that the school at Mission Bay, Fort William Reserve, was completely destroyed by fire on the 31st ultimo.

In reply, I beg to say that you should forward further particulars as to the cause of the fire. There is a teacher's residence in connection with this school and you should state whether this building has also been destroyed.

The Department understands that there is $1,000 insurance on the school building and $1200 on the teacher's residence. When the insurance is received by you, you should forward it to the Department for credit to the account of the Band.

As this school has been closed for sometime and there is very little likelihood of it being reopened, the question of the erection of a new building can remain in abeyance.

The Department will expect a full report from you regarding the cause of this fire, and the insurance collected.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. R. Brown, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.
Sir,

Re fire at Mission Bay School I beg to advise that former Chief Frank Williams allowed a summer camper to use the building but neglected to warn him that the fireplace chimney was defective.

The teachers residence was not damaged. I will forward the insurance money soon as it is received.

There are not enough children at Mission Bay to warrant reopening of a school.

Your obedient servant

Our letter of May 27th, last, authorized an expenditure not exceeding the above amount, and you were instructed to carry out any alterations which you considered necessary in order to provide sufficient classroom accommodation. As yet, no accounts have been received covering any such expenditure and, consequently, the Department presumes that this matter has not yet received your attention.

Mr. Inspector Bennett, who visited this school on the 11th instant, states as follows: (1) the entrance steps are broken; (2) the cellar is in very bad condition; (3) the teacher's kitchen and bedroom have no privacy from the pupils entering and leaving the school; (4) a porcelain jacket is required for the pipe hole; (5) a new chimney is needed before the pipes can be put up, and (6) a large stove should be secured in order to give more heat in the classroom.

The Department trusts that you will take immediate steps to make this building as comfortable as possible, keeping in mind the matters which Mr. Inspector Bennett states are urgent. The expense incurred should not exceed your estimate of $200.

As it is considered that a number of the articles which Inspector Bennett states are required for the teacher's residence were in the Mountain Village School, the Department would like to have a list showing the articles, etc., removed from Mountain Village to Mission Bay. Possibly you have removed these since the date of Mr. Bennett's visit, but we desire to have definite information on this matter.

Kindly advise the dimensions of the additional blackboard required, and an order will be placed for same.

The Department trusts that you will give all these matters your immediate attention.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. R. Brown, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.

Extract from Inspector's Report on the MISSION BAY School, April 1, 1924.

There is no clock of any kind except the teacher's wrist watch and even that needs attention. Could even a small alarm clock be provided?

The teacher has no washboard. She says it is difficult to wash the towels used by the Indian children without one.

When she wants to iron clothes she has to borrow one. Two flat irons for ironing would not cost much.

New fire brick needed in the stove.

This combined teacher's residence and school is in a rather poor condition. The interior of the teacher's rooms appear fair but the interior of the classroom is forbidding. Rain enters under windows. The plaster is falling from the ceiling.

Desks are all broken; the pipes continually smoke when a strong fire is on, although the chimney and pipes were cleaned.

However, the building is not a suitable one in any way. I hope a new school and residence combined will be provided.

J. M. Bennett, INSP.
Ottawa, April 29th, 1924.

Sir:

Mr. J. M. Bennett, Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Mission Bay Indian Day School, requests that certain supplies be given for the teacher's use. You may, therefore, arrange for the purchase and delivery of the following: 1 alarm clock, inexpensive; 1 wash board and 2 flat irons.

The Inspector states that new fire brick are needed in the stove, and you should arrange to have the brick supplied and installed.

Regarding the classroom, the Inspector states that rain enters under the windows and the plaster is falling from the ceiling. You should arrange to have the repairs required to the plaster carried out, and any repairs required made around the windows, in order to prevent the rain from entering.

The Inspector further states that the desks are all broken. You will be good enough to furnish a report regarding the condition of the desks and whether or not they can be repaired. If any new desks are required, you should state the number, sizes and whether double or single.

When you have made the purchase of the above authorized supplies and have completed the repairs authorized to the plaster and windows, you should furnish properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred.

Please give these matters your prompt attention.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

When paying the Indians of the Fort William Band who reside at Mission Bay, my attention was called to the difficulties under which the day school is operated. Since the school house was destroyed by fire a few years ago, school has been held in the teacher's residence in a small room upstairs with a low ceiling. I found 16 school children in this small room, furnished with old (and some broken) wooden desks, taught by a very bright young woman, who is most interested in her work, and has carried on since last fall under discouraging conditions, and will continue to do so if there is a chance of improvement before next winter. Please refer to the Inspector's report on this school. The teacher informs me that she fully expects in the near future an attendance of 25 pupils as there are several youngsters approaching school age, and she expects will attend after the fall term commences. The teacher spends her week end in summer at Fort Williams where she has relatives, and one has only to come in contact with her to realize that she is well equipped for the work she has in hand and should receive every encouragement. The residence should have some repairs made to it before another winter in order to make it habitable. The plaster is falling off in places, the roof leaks and the basement is a veritable mud hole, but could be drained at a small cost, as the house is built on sloping ground. A woodshed should also be built at the rear in order to store wood during winter.

The location of this school is near the Fort William Public Park, land for which was purchased from the Band a few years ago, and is becoming a popular resort, so that this portion of the Reserve is bound to be visited by people who come to this resort and the educational facilities are bound to be criticized and the Department blamed, and I am sure the teacher could easily arouse the sympathy of the Press and others if she chose to do so. I informed her to leave it to me, that I would lay the facts before you and felt sure that I would succeed in improving the conditions under which she is labouring.

The foundation of the school house remains and only needs some repairs. On this should be erected a frame structure with one large room with a cloak room partitioned off. It should be plastered and lined with building paper to make it warm. There should be a cement floor in the basement, which the Indians can use for a council house. I took the measurement of this foundation to aid the Architect in preparing plans in event of it being decided to build. They are as follows: Inside wall 4 inches in thickness; 4 windows 20 inches deep and 3 ft. wide; 1 door at 6 ft.; wall is 5 ft. 6 inches in height at the front and 3 ft. 8 in. at the rear where the door is. Steps leading up to front door are necessary. All materials can be landed at the dock at Mission Bay, near the school site. Tenders should be invited both at Port Arthur and Fort William. The contractor and his men could live under canvas. An Inspector should be employed to watch the job. The cost including repairs to residence which should also
be done by the contractor will it is estimated cost $3000, of this $1000 was obtained from Insurance Co. for burned building and is at credit of Account 10, I think. The Indians will not I fear contribute towards the cost as they say that under the Treaty they are entitled to a school, and the Government must provide the funds. There is no other school on this Reserve. One or two Indians will not send their children to any school, and the other Indians asked me if they could not be compelled to do so. Almost all are now anxious for their children to attend school.

If you can find $2000, I would advise taking action at once, and disarm criticism that is bound to come.

(Sgd.) F. H. Paget.

MEMORANDUM

Regarding the communication which you received from Mr. Paget setting forth the necessity for the erection of a school building at Mission Bay on the Fort William Reserve, I beg to say that the former school building was destroyed by fire some years ago, it having been rented by the Agent to an Indian for living purposes. At present school is conducted in part of the teacher's residence, and there is not sufficient accommodation for the number of pupils, viz., 25, who could attend. Mr. Paget has given the dimensions of the foundation of the school building, and states that a new building could be erected thereon at a cost of approximately $3,000. We obtained the sum of $1,000 insurance on the old school building, and this was credited to the band account. It would be necessary, besides this amount, to take the sum of $2,000 from the interest at the credit of the Fort William band. The amount at the credit of interest is $9,030, and the band have to their credit in capital the sum of $102,619.

I would recommend that the $1,000 insurance be used, and that the balance, viz., $2,000, be taken from the interest funds at the credit of the band. Mr. Orr could prepare the plans for the building. He has information as to the requirements. If you concur in Mr. Paget's recommendation as to the urgent necessity for the erection of a new building, the funds necessary, over the amount of the insurance on hand from the old building, could be taken from the interest funds of the band, and Mr. Orr should be requested to prepare the plans and call for tenders.

Besides the new school building, certain repairs are required to the teacher's residence and a woodshed should be erected.

Sir,

It will be necessary to supply desks for the new school building which is being erected at Mission Bay. As the classroom will accommodate approximately twenty-four children, desks will be required for that number.

The type of desk we supply is the single desk and they are manufactured in the following sizes to accommodate children of various ages:

- Size No. 3 for pupils 12 to 18 years.
- Size No. 4 for pupils 9 to 14 years.
- Size No. 5 for pupils 6 to 10 years.
- Size No. 6 for pupils 5 to 8 years.

It would be advisable to arrange the desks in four rows in the classroom, the smaller at the front and the larger at the rear. I would suggest that the following be supplied, namely:

- 4 x No. 6 Fronts
- 4 x No. 6 Decks
- 4 x No. 5
- 4 x No. 4
- 4 x No. 3 Rears

Please consult the teacher and ascertain from her whether the sizes of desks mentioned and the number of each size will be satisfactory. If not, please have her prepare a list of the number of desks she requires of each size. Also, please state whether you recommend that a teacher's desk and chair and two visitors chairs be supplied.

It will be necessary also to have a cupboard in the classroom for the storing of school material. The contract does not call for this work but it is thought that you might be able to arrange with the contractor to build a small cupboard with a lock and key which would be suitable for the purpose.

Blackboards are included in the contract and will be installed by the contractor.

Kindly reply at an early date, giving full information regarding the desks. You should also give full shipping directions.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

Agreement made in duplicate the THIRTEENTH day of OCTOBER, 1924.

A.D.

Between His Majesty King George the Fifth, represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs of Canada (hereinafter called the Superintendent General);

AND Frank Law & J.A. Burton,

of 31 Emerson Ave., Port Arthur, (hereinafter called the Contractors).

The Contractors for themselves, their heirs, executors, administrators and assigns, agree to do in the most workmanlike manner all works and provide all the materials of the best kind shown in the drawings and described in the specifications marked "A" and "B" respectively and signed by the Contractors and to complete, furnish and hand over to the Superintendent General or to some person by him appointed for that purpose the erection and completion of Indian Day School at Mission Bay, near Fort William, Ont., according to plan and specification No. 548.

and all other work and labour incidental to and necessary for the entire completion thereof, whether specified or shown in the drawings or specifications or not, by the day of A.D.

AND in consideration of the above agreement on the part of the Contractors the Superintendent General hereby agree to pay the said Contractors the sum of Three Thousand three hundred dollars, provided always that the Superintendent General may at any time during the progress or after the completion or alleged completion of the work appoint an Architect, Engineer or other officer, in which case the certificate of such Architect, Engineer or other officer, that the work is duly completed and of the amount, if any, due to the Contractors after making such allowances for penalties and for defective or incomplete work, or for extras and deviations as the Architect, Engineer or other officer shall think fair, shall be a condition precedent to any claim by the Contractors under this contract.

AND the Contractors for themselves their executors, administrators and assigns, further covenant and agree:

1. That the wages to be paid in the execution of this contract shall be those generally accepted as current in each trade for competent workmen in the district where the work is carried on. If this condition is violated the Superintendent General may cancel the contract and refuse to accept any work done thereunder.

2. That if the Contractors fail at any time to pay any account for any goods or materials supplied, or money advanced by anyone to the said Contractors for the purposes of this agreement, or to pay the account of any sub-contractor for any work or materials done or supplied for the said works to be constructed under this agreement, and such
account is in either of such cases one month overdue, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractors to pay such account and if a week elapse and the same be not paid in full, the Superintendent General may pay such account and may charge the same to the Contractors, and the Contractors covenant with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

3. That if the Contractors fail at any time in paying salaries or wages of any person employed by them upon or in respect of the said works, or any of them, and any part of such salary is one month in arrear, or if there be due to any such person one month's wages or salary, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractors to pay such salary or wages, and if two days elapse and the same be not paid in full up to date of payment, or to such other date as may be in accordance with the terms of employment of such person, then the Superintendent General may pay to such person his salary or wages from any date to any date and to any amount which may be payable, and may charge the same to the Contractors and the Contractors covenant with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

4. That pursuant to the Statute in that behalf, this Agreement is made subject to the express condition that no member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of this Agreement or any benefit to arise therefrom.

5. That the Contractors shall not assign, transfer or set over this contract or any interest therein to any person or persons whomsoever, without the consent, in writing, of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs first had and obtained.

IN WITNESS WHEREOF the said Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, acting as aforesaid and the said Frank Law and J. A. Burton, have hereunto set their hands and seals the day and year first above mentioned.

[Signatures]

Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs

Sir:-

The Separate School Inspector in a report on his recent inspection of the Mission Bay Indian Day School on the Fort William Reserve states that certain supplies are required.

I have therefore to request that you will arrange for the purchase and delivery of the following, viz.,

You should arrange to have any repairs required to these toilets carried out and, if necessary they should be thoroughly cleaned. When you have purchased the supplies above authorized and have the toilets placed in good sanitary condition, you should forward properly certified vouchers in duplicate covering the expenditure incurred.

The Inspector further states that the lighting of the school is subject to much criticism. The windows are on one side but the blackboards have been placed at wrong end of school together with platform and teacher's desk. As a result the light is from the right of the scholars and they are continually writing in shadow and light is striking their eyes from wrong direction. Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 17th inst., regarding the lighting of the Mission Bay Day School situated on the Fort William Indian Reserve. In reply I beg to advise; on receipt of your letter I visited the above mentioned school with Inspector O'Rourke of Port Arthur who advised not changing the platform or blackboard. Extract from Report of Inspector Bennett on the Mission Bay Indian Day School - dated May 25th, 1926.

Teachers Residence - Appears in as good condition as can be expected but in Hall - Kitchen and Bedroom the outside coating of Plaster is falling off all over and should be attended to, and the kitchen oilcloth is a mass of holes everywhere.

School Building - Walls should be decorated in some other color than white. There is absolutely nothing to relieve the bare whiteness of the walls. Couldn't some pictures be gathered from some place. Basement has water in it as usual.

Give this teacher a can of paint and she will paint upstairs floor.
Ottawa, June 4th, 1926.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Mission Bay School on the Fort William Reserve, recommends that the walls of the classroom be decorated in some other colour than white, as there is nothing to relieve the bare whiteness of the walls. He also recommends that some pictures be placed on the walls to overcome this condition, and you might report on this matter, stating whether some inexpensive pictures of subjects suitable for a classroom could be obtained, and, if so, the approximate cost.

The Inspector also states that if the teacher were supplied with a can of paint, she would arrange to paint the upstairs floor. Please consult the teacher in this matter, and arrange to supply her with the paint required for the purpose. You should forward certified vouchers in the usual manner for the expenditure incurred for the purpose.

Ottawa, July 9, 1926.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, giving an estimate of the cost of the material and labour in painting the walls of the classroom at the Mission Bay Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say it is considered that your estimate for the paint - $40.00 - is high. Would it not serve the purpose if the walls were calcimined or murescoed instead of being painted? Please inform the Department further regarding this change in the materials to be used. I may say that our funds are very limited this year, and, if calcimining would be satisfactory, you should give an estimate of the cost of the material and labour required. When we have this information, further consideration will be given as to whether any work can be authorized or not.

Relative to the pictures, the Department will approve of an expenditure not exceeding $10. You should consult the teacher as to what pictures she requires and arrange for the purchase of same. However, they should not be placed on the walls until after it is decided what decorating will be done. Please forward itemized accounts, in duplicate, covering the cost of the pictures obtained.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk, Esq.,

Sir:

With further reference to my letter of July 6th regarding decorating the walls of the Mission Bay Day School at Fort William Indian Reserve and your letter of the 9th ult., which I was unable to answer as I was out of town on treaty payments.

In reply wish to advise I have again taken the matter up and find that the cost of calcimining including the material required will be approximately $35.00 to $40.00. This would be a saving of $15.00.

The inspector advised painting the walls as he said the children were apt to mark the walls and if they are painted they can easily be washed.

I have obtained prices from the T. Eaton Co. at Toronto and find I can purchase the paint for $30.00 and I would strongly recommend using paint as it will last much longer.

Would you kindly advise me as soon as possible if you would consider calcimining satisfactory or would you prefer paint. An early reply would be appreciated as I would like to complete this work before the end of September when Miss Lavelle will return.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

J.G. BURK, Indian Agt.
Ottawa, August 28, 1926.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, relative to the decorating of the walls of the Mission Bay Indian Day School, and recommending that these walls be painted instead of kalsomined.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of your arranging to have the interior walls of this building painted. The total cost of the material and labour should not exceed the sum of $55, or a lower cost if possible to do so. You should arrange for the purchase of the quantity of paint required and of the colour considered by you to be suitable. You should also arrange for the labour and have the work done before the school reopens. When this work is finished, you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the cost of the material and labour.

We note that Miss Lavelle, the teacher, will not resume duties until the end of September. As she closed this school for the summer holidays about the middle of July last, it is considered that she should, in order to complete the ten teaching months in the next school year, open this school about the middle of September, next.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
For Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. G. Burk, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.

on his inspection of the Mission Bay Indian Day School, dated May 2nd, 1927.

Original on File 9-13-6.

"1. Furnace couldn't be used since chimney was too small and the pupils were smoked out. A box stove had to be placed in the class-room.

"2. At least 6 inches of water has been in the cellar. It is used for wood only so it doesn't matter. Besides the teacher has her own house."

"1. This reserve does not possess any clocks in their homes; besides, if they did they wouldn't keep time. Consequently, there is need of a school bell (as on other school buildings) on the reserve. Can you supply one?

"Miss Lavelle is doing well for you. She accomplishes more with these children than I have seen in many other day schools. However, in spite of their progress, the deficiency in imagination in the Indian race is seen - Mental arithmetic, and kindred tests."
Ottawa, May 7th, 1927.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Mission Bay Indian Day School, states that the furnace in this building could not be used as the chimney is too small, and, as a consequence, the room fills with smoke. To overcome this difficulty he states a box stove had to be used in the classroom. Please furnish a report as to whether you would recommend any alterations be made in the chimney, or whether the present arrangement for the heating of this building by a stove is satisfactory.

The Inspector also states that there is considerable water in the cellar, which is used for the storage of wood only. Please report regarding this matter and state what steps you would recommend be taken to provide proper drainage, and the cost of having the work done.

The Inspector recommends that a school bell be installed on the school building. Please state whether there is any tower or other place on the roof in which a bell having a weight, with mounting, of approximately 275 pounds could be installed. If not, you might state whether this bell could be installed in a special stand erected on the school grounds, and, if so, what it would cost to put up an inexpensive stand for the purpose.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. G. Burk, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur,
Ont.

Sir,

RE: Mission Bay Day School.

Referring to your letter of the 7th inst., file number 9-13-5, and my reply of the 12th relative to the Separate School Inspector's report on the Mission Bay Indian Day School. The furnace in this school was not used last winter as it would invariably smoke when the draft was turned on full. Consequently I thought it advisable to install a box stove, which is far more satisfactory and does not burn one quarter of the wood. The teacher informed me the box stove gives much more satisfaction than the furnace as the children are able to dry their mittens in the winter time.

Personally I would not recommend any alterations to the chimney as the present arrangements for heating this school are very satisfactory.

Referring to the second paragraph of your letter regarding the water in the school basement, the cost of installing a drain would be approximately $25.00, as the formation of the ground is very rocky.

Personally I would not recommend this expenditure as the water only seeps through the basement in one corner for a few weeks in the spring and seems to dry up very quickly.

Referring to the third paragraph of your letter regarding a school bell installed on the school building which would weigh approximately 275 lbs I wish to advise that a special stand could be erected on the school grounds for approximately $20.00. There is no tower on the school roof, but a suitable stand could be erected which would cost about $25.00 or $30.00.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burtt,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, May 31st, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 28th instant, relative to the furnace and drainage at the Mission Bay Indian Day School referred to by the Separate School Inspector in a report on his recent inspection of this school. In this connection it is noted that you do not recommend any alterations to the chimney or to the present heating arrangement at the school, which you state are satisfactory, also that you do not recommend any expenditure in connection with drainage of the water in the school basement. No further action need, therefore, be taken regarding these matters.

Relative to a school bell, we are obtaining prices here and will place the order for a suitable bell. The weight of the bell and mountings which we will supply will be approximately 200 pounds. The bell on which we are obtaining prices is 22" in diameter, and will be satisfactory for the purpose for which it is required. You may arrange to have a special stand erected on the school grounds for this bell, and when the bell arrives it can be installed thereon. We note that you estimate the cost of erecting this stand to be approximately $20. It should be built in a position on the grounds convenient to the school and not interfering with the playground activities. The Department will pay any expenses in having the bell installed, and you may forward properly certified vouchers in the usual manner covering the expenditure incurred in the building of the stand and installing of the bell. We will inform you in a few days of the name of the firm from whom the bell will be obtained.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

Enclosed herewith please find requisition for the Mission Bay Indian Day School at Fort William which was telephoned in. The school teacher also asked for the following supplies:

5 lb. tin of Cocoa.
2½ doz. cups.
2½ doz. spoons.
6 dish towels.
1 fine pan,
1 Broom.
1 Coleman's coal oil Lamp.

The lamp is to be used in the school. The lamp the teacher has in her residence is a gasoline one and the teacher considers it rather dangerous to carry it from one place to the other.

Miss Lavelle just informed me the children have to walk a considerable distance to the school and the teacher deems it advisable to give them a hot drink of cocoa just before leaving and a hot drink at the noon hour.

Consequently I would strongly recommend purchasing the cocoa and the other necessary supplies.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 10th inst., file No. 9-13-5, relative to my requisition for school supplies for the Mission Bay Day School, Fort William Reserve, and referring to your third paragraph I beg to report that the Coleman Coal Oil Lamp will be used in the Mission Bay School after school hours.

Miss Lavelle, who teaches in this school, advised me that she conducts a great number of sewing classes in the school house after school hours. These classes are generally held during the winter months when artificial light is required.

A great number of school concerts are also held in the school house during the winter months, which is a great source of entertainment for the school children and their parents. These concerts also encourage the parents to send their children to school.

Consequently I would recommend purchasing this lamp as it will undoubtedly assist the teacher in her work.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

I beg to advise that the Fort William Indian Reserve is divided into what is known as Squaw Bay and Mountain Village—a distance of 4 miles separates these two factions. The Band have erected a small council house at Mountain Village, and have been in the habit of using the school house at Squaw Bay once or twice annually for council meetings when anything of importance is brought up.

Recently a council meeting was held in the Mission Bay School House when 2 companies applied for separate leases to operate rock quarries. I wish to advise the council house and school house is always thoroughly washed and cleaned after each council meeting.

Ottawa, June 11th, 1929.

Sir,

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Mission Bay Indian Day School, states that some minor repairs are required around the windows and that the plaster should be repaired. He also recommends that a cupboard for the storing of books, etc., be provided.

Please furnish a report regarding any repairs required to the interior of the building and, if you consider same is necessary, you should forward an estimate of the cost of supplying a cupboard that would be suitable for the storing of books and school supplies.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

Port Arthur, Ont.,
June 26th, 1929.

Sir:

With reference to the Mission Bay Day School I beg to advise that the kitchen walls and the back stairs walls should be kalsomined. The approximate cost of this work would be $5.00 to $8.00.

I would also recommend that 1 quart of Floor Oil should be purchased for the Mission Bay Day School, and two quarts of Varnish for the teacher's residence.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk,

Ottawa, June 29, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th instant, relative to the kalsomining required to the kitchen walls and back stairs at the Mission Bay Indian Day School. In reply I have to say that you may arrange to have the kalsomining required carried out. It is noted that you estimate the approximate cost of this work to not exceed $5.

You may purchase 1 quart floor oil for the day school and 2 quarts varnish for the teacher's residence.

Please forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Sir:

With further reference to my letter of April 10, No. 210-4A, drawing the Department's attention to the 3 school toilets directly back of the Mission Bay school and residence, which are in a frightfully dilapidated condition caused by a very severe windstorm several weeks ago. Unfortunately the buildings are too old to repair. Consequently 3 new toilets should be erected, which will cost approximately $25.00.

Recommendation was also made for kalsomining the kitchen, living room, and bedroom of the Mission Bay school residence. This school is heated by a wood stove, and the walls have become very dark, which no doubt was caused by smoke.

I would also strongly recommend that the kitchen, sitting room, and hall floors be painted. The teacher informed me she would be very pleased to do the kalsomining, also the painting if the Department would purchase the necessary material costing approximately $15.00.

The curtains in the sitting room of the residence have not been replaced for a great number of years. Consequently I would recommend purchasing inexpensive curtains for the sitting room.

An early reply will be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Ottawa, June 5, 1931.

Sir:

I have your No. 210-4A of the first instant, relative to the condition of the toilets at the Mission Bay Indian Day School. It is noted that they are in a dilapidated condition and that you recommend having three new toilets erected, at a cost of approximately $25. In this connection I have to request that you will furnish further information as to the type of toilet you recommend. Also please state why three are required. The Department considers it doubtful if new toilets could be erected for the amount stated by you. Therefore, I shall be pleased to have full information as to what work you recommend be carried out in regard to these toilets.

With reference to the calcimining of the kitchen, living room and bedroom of the residence and the painting of the kitchen, sitting room and hall floors, I have to say that the Department will approve of your incurring an expenditure not exceeding approximately $15 in the purchase of the calcimine and paint required for this purpose. It is noted that the teacher will perform the work of calcimining and painting without cost to the Department. Further, you may arrange for the purchase of inexpensive curtains for the sitting room. After you have purchased the above authorized supplies, please forward itemized accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 17th inst., No. 9-13-5, with reference to voucher No. 64-7, amounting to $4.00 covering coal oil supplied to the Mission Bay Indian Day School. In reply I beg to report that the oil is used in the teacher's residence both for cooking and lighting purposes. With reference to purchasing oil for cooking purposes at various schools I find the oil is more economical than wood for cooking.

With reference to the Mission Bay Day School I wish to report this school is equipped with a 3½ foot camp heater which supplies sufficient heat for the school residence. The teacher does considerable cooking on this stove, but is also obliged to use the oil stove for baking, etc.

In conclusion I would refer you to official letter of June 6, 1932, No. 9-3-8, in which the Department advised it would be in order to continue supplying Indian Day schools with coal oil for both lighting and cooking.

EXD.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 4th instant the Department will allow an expenditure of $48.62 for the purchase of a new heater and for making minor repairs at the Mission Bay Indian day school.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.
Sir:

I beg to report on a recent visit to the Mission Bay Indian Day school, Fort William reserve I found that the residence and school was badly in need of repairs and also required a new heater. I am attaching herewith, a list of what is required with the approximate cost.

This school is quite frequently visited by Tourists and citizens of the Twin Cities of Fort William and Port Arthur and at the present time is in a very dilapidated condition.

The heater, mentioned above, is required for the classroom. The one in use at the present time is badly burned and as a drum type heater is required, I would recommend that same be purchased from the Piper hardware Co. in Fort William, who have several of this type now on hand, that were purchased from the Fort William band and which were manufactured last year at the Factory which was operating on the reserve at that time.

As the season has now set in I would urge that authorization be granted to make these purchases as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk, Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

MEMORANDUM

April 12, 1940

THE DEPUTY MINISTER

RUSH

A letter (bearing postal date April 10) is received this morning, addressed to the Minister, from the Rev. Dan McIvor, M.P., Port Arthur, which reads as follows:

"The School at Squaw Bay Mission & Residence is in a dilapidated condition & must be replaced for I think it is useless to try & repair it. I have examined it. This school is visited by many tourists & citizens & so it is a poor recommendation for our Government.

"I would ask for your consideration & co-operation as soon as possible".

Will you please have the matter looked into at the earliest possible moment, and be good enough to have a draft letter prepared for my signature, acknowledging the correspondence in the Minister's absence and replying thereto.

W.J.W. Pratt
Private Secretary.

Ottawa, April 15, 1940.

Re: Mission Bay Indian Day School

Dear Sir:

The Minister is in receipt of a letter from the Reverend Dan. McIvor, M. P., Port Arthur, Ont., which reads in part as follows:

"The school at Squaw Bay Mission and residence are in a dilapidated condition and must be replaced. I think it is useless to try and repair these buildings."

No provision has been made in the 1940-41 estimates for the construction of an Indian day school at Mission Bay and I may add that with one or two exceptions our building program for this year has been completely suspended. However, you might make an inspection of this school and send forward to the Department information regarding the type of building by which the present structure might be replaced, the approximate cost, etc. I am anxious to secure these details, in the hope that, if conditions change, we may be in a position to make provision for the building of a school at this point in the 1941-42 estimates.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.
Ottawa, April 15, 1940.

Dear Mr. McIvor:

In the absence of the Minister, I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of April 10, in which you intimate that in your judgment steps should be taken to replace the Squaw Bay Mission Indian day school.

The officials of the Indian Affairs Branch inform me that no provision has been made in the 1940-41 estimates for the construction of a new school at this point. I should add that in view of war conditions our building program has been very drastically curtailed. The records indicate, however, that in response to requests from the Indian agent repairs at an approximate cost of $65.00 were undertaken at this school in November, 1938, and repairs to the extent of $49.00 in December, 1939.

The officials feel, however, that this particular building is in a dilapidated condition and it is their intention to communicate with the Indian agent, asking him to make an inspection of the school and to send forward an estimate of the amount that would be required, should it be decided to proceed with the erection of a school during the fiscal year 1941-42.

Yours sincerely,

W. J. F. Pratt,
Private Secretary.

Reverend Dan. McIvor, M.P.,
Port Arthur, Ontario.

In reply to your letter of the 15th ultimo, file No. 9-13-5, with regard to a letter received by the Minister in connection with the condition of the above noted school, I beg to report that at the present time, the teacher's residence and the school classroom are two separate buildings. The teacher's residence is a two-story building, of four rooms with concrete foundation. The classroom is a one story building consisting only of one room, this also has a concrete foundation. Both buildings are of frame construction and are heated with heaters. They are very old buildings and in a very dilapidated condition and would cost a considerable sum of money to even put them in fair condition. I would not recommend spending any money in repairs as, due to their age, they would require a considerable expenditure from year to year in maintenance.

For the past two years, the amount of $5,500.00 has been placed in our estimates, for the construction of a combination school and residence, similar to the schools now in use at Gull Bay, Mobert and other day schools in the agency. Owing to the sharp increase in the cost of materials during the past few months, however, I have had a new estimate made and find that to construct a building of this type, at the present time, the cost would be around $6,700.00. This figure is based, however, using all white labour and I believe would be reduced to about $6,000.00 using Indian labour wherever possible.

The type of building, we have in mind is outlined by Departmental plan No. 532 and designated as "Plan of Oka Indian Day school, Oka, Que." This type of building is far more economical with regard to repairs and maintenance, as well as being more convenient for the teacher and pupils.

I will take this matter up with Mr. Burk, the agent, on his return and if a more detailed report is required, the matter can be given more time, with regard to details of material, labour etc.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, with reference to the Mission Bay School and teacher's residence.

No funds were provided in the current year's appropriation for the erection of a new school or teacher's residence at any point in Canada. You will therefore realize that it is impossible for the Department to consider building a teacher's residence at Mission Bay this year.

Mr. J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.
Extract from Inspector Greening's report on the Mission Bay Indian Day School visited on May 12, 1942.

I feel, however, that with the increasing scarcity of teachers, it will become more and more difficult to keep a really good teacher at this school unless some kind of a decent residence is provided, in which connection I would draw attention to my last report on this school.

In my opinion it would be a waste of money to try to put the old residence into any kind of habitable condition. It would cost a good deal, and, after the money had been spent, there would be little to show for it. Moreover, the actual school classroom building's wall has the plaster badly broken and needs other repairs. As I have said, the classroom is now kept beautifully neat and tidy, but a teacher can have little heart in trying to keep it so, when the main wall, the one she is facing most of the time, is "plastered" with old cardboard cartons.

While the external appearance of the school is not too bad, the old residence is really an eyesore, which is the more to be regretted since the buildings are within easy distance of Fort William, with the result that a good many people pass them, especially during the warmer weather. I have, myself, heard disparaging remarks made of the buildings which are a poor return to the Department for the interest it takes in its schools.

The ideal solution would be to build a new combined school and residence and tear down both the old buildings. (They are adjacent to the new hospital and add nothing to its attractiveness.) However, it is realized that, during these times, strict economy is vitally necessary, and that all unnecessary expenditures must be ruthlessly eliminated. The foregoing remarks, however, are submitted so that the situation may be fully understood.

In view of what has just been said the Agent requests authority to make local purchase of the materials required in order that the work may proceed immediately. I should appreciate receiving this authority.

In regard to the paint, the Agent states that several local firms in Port Arthur are advertising paint at reduced prices at the present time and he believes that it might be possible to make some saving by taking advantage of the sale prices.

Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Fort Arthur, Ont.,
April 19, 1943.

Referring to our verbal conversation on March 17th during my visit to Ottawa, in connection with a grant of $350.00 to complete repairs on the Mission Bay Indian day school and residence, I would appreciate if you could forward an advance cheque of $150.00 to cover labour in this regard.

As this is a very old building it is extremely difficult to ascertain the exact amount of materials required I would appreciate if authority could be granted to purchase material locally as the work progresses and as it is required.
